TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister will be aware that Australia invited the Royal Navy to be part of our bicentennial celebrations. Will the Prime Minister now apologise to the British Government and the captain and the crew of the British aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal following the union actions which prevented the ship from docking in Melbourne? —I am pleased at last to get a question from the Leader of the Opposition. It has been a long time coming, and on what a profoundly important subject. I am disappointed that elements of those fleets which were visiting Australia for our bicentennial celebrations and which played such an important part in adding to the lustre of those celebrations were not able to complete the whole of their proposed program. It is fairly well-known that I give no comfort or support to those whose actions, together with the weather, prevented the Melbourne part of the program being finalised. Knowing as I do the understanding that all overseas governments have of my commitment and that of my Government to the success of these programs, I dismiss the question for the stupid and irrelevant one that it is.
—Can the Prime Minister inform the House of underlying trends in the Australian economy, particularly in the light of recent employment indicators?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The employment statistics released last week indicate a continued high job growth plus, I am pleased to say, increased work force participation. As honourable members who are interested in the economy would know, employment rose by some 46,600 to be, on a trend basis, some 3.8 per cent above the level of a year ago, and the participation rate rose by a further 0.2 per cent to reach 62.6 per cent. This gives us the figure, for the period in which we have had responsibility for the control of this economy, of an increase in employment of 1,143,000, or an increase which is twice the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average. To give a comparison with those opposite, that rate of employment growth is four times as fast as the rate of employment growth under our predecessors.

ANSWER.PARA: The process of structural adjustment is continuing because we have returned real unit labour costs in this country to the level that applied at the end of the 1960s. The level of industrial disputes, which occasionally interests those opposite, is 60 per cent lower under this Government than it was under the Fraser-Howard Government. The average annual rate of manufacturing investment has increased under my Government three times faster than under the Fraser-Howard Government. It is a pleasure to report that in 1986 real manufacturing exports increased by around 15 per cent while last year they increased by some 13 per cent. It is known that the last Budget saw the elimination of the net public sector borrowing requirement, due largely to the third successive year of falls in real Commonwealth Government outlays.

As well as those magnificent achievements in the macro-economy, it is also recognised that in the area of micro-economic reform and agenda this Government has gone far beyond anything that has been attempted or achieved in this country before. At the same time as we have had remarkable achievements in macro-economic management and reform of the micro-economy, we have not lost sight of the fact that social justice reform must be an integral part, as it has been in the agenda of this Government.

At a time of supreme economic challenge for this country we have provided-through me, the Treasurer and other Ministers-strong leadership in the context of the right policy prescriptions. That record is clear and it speaks for itself. Yet when we look for the Opposition's policy alternatives we find none. When we look to the other side for any policy prescriptions we find none at all. The absence of policies from the other side is in stark contrast to the unequivocal promises that the Leader of the Opposition made to the people of this country earlier this year. He said in February of this year that he had a timetable for the release of policies. On 15 February he said:
I have said all along that the timetable for policy release is by August . . . that is going to be adhered to.

Of course, he had to be saying something earlier this year about the release of policy because in fact Professor Hewson, as he was before he came into this place, had mugged the Leader of the Opposition for the fact that he had not produced policies. I remind you, Mr Acting Speaker--

—Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy advise the House of the implications of the Government's decision to change the pricing arrangements for liquefied petroleum gas (LPG)? In particular, can the Minister indicate whether local government gas supply authorities in New South Wales have any reason to be concerned by the changed arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Tuesday the Prime Minister announced the Government's decision to change the current arrangements governing wholesale LPG prices. Under the new system the maximum basic wholesale price of LPG will be determined by the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA). This will put LPG pricing on the same basis as that of other petroleum products. More significantly, it will remove the rigidities inherent in the current arrangements. Like so many of the regulations imposed by the previous Government, the current LPG pricing arrangements are a disincentive to production and investment. By allowing the PSA to take all relevant factors into account, the Government will remove the current disincentive to investment in the infrastructure that will be necessary to meet expanding domestic demands. It will also remove the disincentive to LPG production in general and the mismatch in the pattern of supply and demand between propane and butane in particular.

ANSWER.PARA: There are two important features of the arrangement that I want to stress. Firstly, export controls on LPG will be retained subject to review after 18 months. Controls will apply only if problems emerge in supplying domestic markets, otherwise Australians producers will be able to export LPG under automatic annual approval. Of course, the Government hopes that it will not be necessary to intervene through export controls but it will do so if supply problems emerge. Secondly, in addressing very directly the question of the honourable member for Calare, the continued price control by the PSA will ensure that consumers, particularly small consumers in the transport and domestic sectors, are not disadvantaged by the exercise of market power by producers. Consumers can be assured that they will be paying no more than the proper economic price for LPG. This is a balanced decision, consistent with the aims of protecting consumers and providing appropriate incentives for production and investment. It will be to the long term benefit of all concerned. Like so many other decisions this Government has taken, it stands in stark contrast to the previous Government's record of ad hoc counterproductive regulations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is no. Today we see an amazing article in the Melbourne Herald. First, having relinquished a position of some prominence as a commentator for the more comfortable isolation of the Melbourne Herald, Mr McCrann now needs to have his paper advertise his columns before anyone will read them-and not only that, but extensively advertise this column. He has disappeared to such a degree that a major advertising spree is needed for him to be at all noticed. The second thing he does is take the bat to the Canberra Press Gallery, stating in the article:

ANSWER.PARA: Rhetoric and bluster might be able to convince the journalists in the Canberra press gallery . . .

He goes on to talk about how much other people understand. He argues on the basis that he alone understands the concept of fiscal drag; that no enlightened person in the Canberra Press Gallery does. Not only that, but that the Prime Minister and I have been cheating the nation of income. The whole analysis is flawed and wrong. It is flawed on the basis that it is not fiscal drag if a person's average tax rate increases because his income increases. It is not fiscal drag because people have a higher income. Mr McCrann has taken the tax ratio of tax paid to taxable income, and compared that ratio, which he projects to 1988-89-he does not have any data for it-with the ratio for 1982-83. TALK.START.PARA: —He has just discovered the drought.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—In a year when production was higher, for instance, a farmer would have an increase in his or her tax ratio. Of course he would, because there was more income. But by dividing the tax paid by the tax payable Mr McCrann has sought to imply a ratio that all of that represents fiscal drag. ANSWER.PARA: Importantly also, it can't be explained away by revenue-raising moves against tax avoidance, or widening the tax base, as that by definition produces a higher taxable income figure.

The ratio of tax paid to taxable income is higher because more people are paying their fair share of tax. The Prime Minister and I are not cheating the electorate; we are making other cheats pay. The arrogance of the situation is such that we have this massive advertising campaign about a series of articles which are entirely flawed in their conceptual analysis. He bags the Canberra Press Gallery and then seeks to lift his profile as an economic commentator.

I conclude on this point: I was at a lunch with Mr McCrann and News Ltd executives earlier this year. He was seeking to display his knowledge by leading the band at this News Ltd discussion. I said, `Listen, Terry, before you open your mouth, let me make this point: you are a marked man; you are a Liberal; you support the Liberal Party'. There was no rebuttal and no defence. This Government has restructured the Australian economy, as the Prime Minister said, made it a market economy, floated the exchange rate, removed exchange controls, changed the financial system, run a big deficit down to a surplus and cut outlays, but there has not been one commendatory note from Mr McCrann, who is just a partisan sitting in a highly paid backwater in the Melbourne Herald and who is conceptually wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Treasurer. As a result of his recent attendance at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and meetings with world financial leaders, will the Treasurer inform the House of the current state of the world economy and the implications for Australia?
—How many people listened to the IMF speech?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to report that I found the meetings and engagements which I attended recently with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank considerably upbeat in their nature. People thought this burst of growth--
—People back here--

—In some parts of the world people take the debate seriously. I know that Play School has been in here for a few weeks with the lot opposite. I thought of buying them some blocks, as I came through Singapore, to play with on the carpet.
—How many people came to listen to the IMF speech?
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.

—The fact is that the world economy is continuing to grow well and there is a view around the world that, although we have had six years of continuous growth and now, at the end of that period, some attendant rise in inflation, that growth ought to be maintained. That is a view held by the people representing the major economies. The fact is that the world economy is continuing to grow well. Gross domestic product (GDP) was up 3 3/4 per cent in 1988, with world trade growing by 7 per cent, which is the strongest rate of growth in recent times. Of the major economies, Japan is growing strongly. The Japanese Government has turned around the balance of its economic policies to support domestic demand, now rising by 7 per cent, which has pumped its GDP growth along to a forecast 5 3/4 per cent. So the second major economy is growing very strongly indeed. The balance of that growth is good in terms of running down international trade imbalances. The United States economy is growing close to 4 per cent in 1988, while growth in Germany has picked up to around 2 1/4 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Underpinning that general buoyancy in general activity in the majors, the commodity price outlook continues to look solid. That is a view supported by most major country finance Ministers and trade Ministers. Trade is up, the stock position-that is, the stock to sales ratio of major commodities-is much better, and the outlook for bulk traded commodities is particularly better, especially for iron ore and metalliferous coals. So, as I said before, all in all there was an acceptance of the view that there is no need to stop growth after six years and, although monetary policy slackened following the October stock market crash, inflation has moved up moderately in some countries and monetary policy has accordingly been tightened. But there is a willingness on the part of governments around the world to maintain policy flexibility, to keep their economies growing. However, there are some risks. I think one of the risks continues to be the United States--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. It concerns the wasting of Question Time. This is very interesting--
—Order! Does the honourable member for O'Connor have a point of order?

—Mr Acting Speaker, my point of order relates to the fact that the Treasurer's answer would be more appropriate in the form of a statement. Statements are down from about 60 to 20. I ask you to ask the Treasurer to do so. He might also tell us how many people listened to his IMF speech. I counted 10.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.

—As I said, there are some risks. The United States deficit is still too high. There is too much weight put on monetary policy in the United States, which means that the attendant interest rate increases are spreading to the Third World debt. The fact is that a lot of these countries are not getting the growth in trade that one would have assumed as a result of this growth over six years. Obviously, if United States interest rates are rising, that is a burden for those with United States denominated debt, many of which are developing countries, and that contagion in interest rates spreads around the world. We have again made the point, I think reasonably, as other governments did, that we would like to see more balance in the United States economic policy.

ANSWER.PARA: Overwhelmingly, the reaction to Australia is now the belief that it is one of the most flexible countries in the world. As the Prime Minister said earlier, we have got the public sector borrowing requirement to zero. That almost marks us out as unique among the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. The rate of tax changes here, both by their quality and size, is well noted. In particular, our system of full dividend imputation is a world first and is coming under much notice. The change in tariffs, the financial market deregulation, the reduction in real unit labour costs, employment growth tapping the full potential of our work force, strong levels of investment-a forecast 12 per cent this year following 10 per cent last year-and all of these structural changes are being noted as ones which make the Australian economy much more flexible. So the point is that Australia is now better placed to face whatever happens in the world economy but we see the world continuing to grow as strongly as it has in the last few months.

We are getting out of the debt habit. We have a surplus of $5.5 billion. While overseas I announced the repayment of $1.5 billion, on top of the $700m in Tokyo. We will repay $3 billion of overseas debt this year and $2 billion of domestic debt, which is a permanent saving in public debt interest in terms of the Budget. Between 1975 and 1983-that is on the part of the former Government-net overseas raising was $4,488m. Between 1983-84 and this year we will have repaid $1,310m. We are now repaying the debt which the former Treasurer, who is now the Leader of the Opposition, and his colleagues ran up as a government between 1975 and 1983.

It is noticed that we are repaying debt. It went all round the International Monetary Fund and the international banking community that we had repaid Swiss loans, that we had repaid yen denominated debt recently and that we have a program of debt repayment. It is also noted that Australia has a much more flexible approach to economic policy and to its economy and hence there is a lot of interest in what we are doing and how we have done it. I must say that at the end of the visit and the round of talks the outlook for commodity prices remains pretty good and the prospects, therefore, for our current account and for continuing growth in the world look, as I said in the beginning, generally upbeat.

Perhaps part of the reason for that is the extraordinary position of the Opposition, unprecedented in this country, of not putting its shadow spokesman in the Cabinet. We have had several Cabinet changes on the Opposition front bench since the current incumbent in the shadow defence portfolio was appointed. We are well beyond what might have been a period of grace for training, although I recollect that he was a shadow Minister before he was appointed to the defence area.

The Opposition loves to wrap itself in the flag on defence. It loves to take the high ground and make statements that are holier than thou as far as this side of the House is concerned: this side of the House is the only one to produce a coherent defence policy since the early 1970s. What we get from the Opposition is such a level of priority as far as defence is concerned that it appoints two outer Ministry people to run the portfolio. The Opposition should not think that that point is not noticed by the armed services and by our allies and others who have an interest in our defence policy. They note it; they comment on it to me frequently. It is clear that there is a downgrading of the Opposition's position on defence. No wonder, when we see the sort of dross that emanates from the Opposition shadow spokesman. The Opposition could not put him anywhere near a position where his promises on an area of expenditure might be regarded as having any credibility. Fortunately in this area he has no credibility either.

The shifting of our armed forces to the north, which is a policy of this Government, is a commonly recognised essential step in establishing the proper disposition of forces for defence self-reliance in this country. It has hitherto been a point not disagreed on by any sensible commentator on the requirements of the defence of this country, except apparently-and, I might say, daringly-in Darwin by the Opposition defence spokesman, who ignored the fact that we have a substantial amphibious capability in the Tobruk; ignored the fact that we have a substantial amphibious capability in the LCHs; ignored the fact that we have a substantial amphibious capability in regard to the ways in which we might use Stalwart and Jervis Bay; and ignored the fact that amphibious capability is not all that is essential if we intend to send forces elsewhere. If we decide to do that from time to time, we have a substantial airlift capability in our defence forces. The Opposition spokesman ignored all of that and said that we would scale down the movement of our forces to the north. I recollect that in the last election campaign he was fairly disparaging of the notion of priority for shifting them to the west as well. The Opposition has no defence policy. It has had 5 1/2 years to devise a defence policy; it has no respect for the portfolio. For some 12 months it has refused to give Cabinet status to its Opposition shadow spokesman on defence. It is a disgrace. It has no policy in this area, as it has no policy in any area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to the people in the audience in the gallery: You have just witnessed a fairly typical Question Time in the House of Representatives. One of the last Ministers to answer a question was the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). His line was that he had a monopoly on compassion. What was interesting was that, as is typical of the Australian Labor Party, we heard nothing about the rich getting richer and about those in the Labor Party who have their snouts in the trough. The other thing that is interesting is that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is back. Before he fell into his usual routine he struggled to get over the words of support for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). His usual routine was to abuse somebody-heaps of personal abuse-and then out came a load of arrogance.

SPEECH.PARA: I just say to you, Mr Acting Speaker, that the reaction basically from this side of the House is simply this: whilst we are not going to sit here and take the sorts of responses that we have had from the Government today, in the end it will count for nothing because this Government is simply out of touch. I do not think the Treasurer understands that, whilst he was away, the people of Oxley had a message to send to his Government. In fact, Mr 38 per cent came in here with a message in his back pocket for the Prime Minister and the Treasurer.

The reality is that there is a great change of mood in this country today. Honourable members will not read of it in the newspapers or hear of it on the electronic media, but they might pick it up in the talkback. People are saying to this Government, `We no longer believe you. We no longer trust what you have been telling us as to the situation in this country today'. The Treasurer can claim to be the world's greatest Treasurer. It is infectious. We even had the leader of the Australian Council of Trade Unions yesterday say that we had the world's greatest trade unions. Those opposite can say that till they are blue in the face, but nobody will believe them because the penny is starting to drop. People are asking themselves, `They have been in for 5 1/2 years; am I any better off?' Of course, the answer is to be felt in their hip pockets. That is what is happening. That is why we have people such as the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), the Treasurer and other senior Ministers wanting the Prime Minister to get out. They realise that the country is starting to wake up and starting to realise that much of what is being put to them by the Prime Minister in particular is phoney.

When it comes to managing the main game, the Prime Minister is off on another agenda. We can understand the resentment that has been building up between those senior economic Ministers. If honourable members listen to the Treasurer, he will tell them that he sticks to the main game. The last thing that he wants is a Prime Minister diverting from the agenda set by the Treasurer and his campaign manager, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. They look at the Prime Minister and say to themselves, `Here is a bloke who will say absolutely anything to suit the political convenience of the time'. Look at what was said in the electorate of Oxley. He talked his head off and said that the good times are here and the good times are coming-all as a result of his performance as an economic manager. Let us look at his policy and his basic strategic position for the next election. He says, `There will be tax cuts. You ought to be grateful for what we have given you'. Everybody knows the reality of the tax cuts. I will refer to them in a minute.

The Prime Minister simply wants a fourth term. That is his agenda and nothing is to stand in his way. There really is a growing concern with people such as the Treasurer. Why? It is because they have seen it all before-the build-up of expectation as part of a simple political strategy by the Prime Minister. Let us go back to the by-elections that were held for the seats of Adelaide and Port Adelaide earlier this year. One interesting thing that came out of that was a decision in the strategy corridors of the Government to start to build up a situation, a claim, that the hard times, those wartime conditions once referred to not so long ago by the Prime Minister, were now over and that, thanks to the Prime Minister, the good times were coming. One of the real implications, the bottom line implications of the build-up of expectations earlier this year, came in the national wage case in August 1988. Let me read what was said in that decision:
In the light of our appreciation of the economic situation, we think that the wage increases allowed by this decision are the most that we can responsibly grant.
Let me come to the crunch:
There would be significant economic benefits in lower increases, but we acknowledge the force of the non-economic concerns which have a contrary implication.

That might be doublespeak, but the reality is that the Full Bench said: `Look, we had some by-elections earlier in the year in Adelaide and Port Adelaide'. The Government has been talking up expectations as to what people are going to get in their pockets and, as a result, the reality is that the force of the non-economic concerns has a contrary implication. So we had a build-up to the 3 per cent wage increase and the $10 increase at the national wage case in August this year. So it is that people such as the Treasurer and his campaign manager are very concerned, and properly so, that whilst the Prime Minister has been promoting expectations, the ultimate consequence of that will be a non-economic concern having an impact on the broad economic strategy that the Government is attempting to pursue.

The Prime Minister has adopted a very simple line: the hard times are over; let the good times roll on. Of course, we all know that the stark facts are otherwise. Let us look at tax. We would need $56 in our pockets just to put us back where we were in 1983. We have heard the abuse today but, of course, no real response-there is none-to Terry McCrann's comments in today's Melbourne Herald. In his article entitled `The great tax grab', Mr McCrann says:
Paul Keating has presided over the biggest tax grab by any Treasurer in any government in this country's history.
Look at the sharp reality for millions of Australians as a result of Labor's economic policy. The article continues:

More than two million taxpayers have been pushed into the top two tax brackets since 1982-83, and by the close of this financial year a staggering one million of these will have ended up in the top bracket.
Even somebody with taxable income of well below the average weekly male wage is now in that second highest bracket-facing a tax rate of 41.25 per cent on every extra dollar of income.
Once you hit a taxable income of about $1500 a week you are better off than a comparable taxpayer in 1982-83.
The Government is hitting those people in places such as Oxley. That is the message from the people of Oxley. That is the harsh, stark reality. Mr McCrann continues:

The single most striking message is that each and every year he has been treasurer, Mr Keating has seized a higher proportion of the taxable income of the seven million taxpayers in Australia than in the previous year.

He is the biggest taxing Treasurer that we have ever had. The response was abuse at Question Time but, of course, there has been no response to the economic and political problems which have been brought about as a result of this building of expectations and the basic failure of the Government's economic program. Honourable members opposite can exaggerate and employ hyperbole until the cows come home but when people are feeling the pinch, as they are from one end of this country to another, there is in fact no real policy response. So we see in the upper echelons of the Government nothing but division, distraction and conflict between the positions that they have adopted.

After being told that expenditure cuts were a thing of the past, we have had the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), saying, `Expenditure cuts will have to be back on the agenda'. We have had another Minister saying, `Oh well, in respect of tax cuts, they might not be all at once; we might have to stagger them, a bit now and a bit later'. Yesterday, Senator Button said, `We cannot indulge ourselves'. We cannot indulge ourselves! What arrogance. In regard to the taxes paid by the taxpayers of Australia, he is saying that we cannot indulge ourselves. It is no indulgence to say that we are paying too much tax. This Government has not just got its hand in the taxpayer's pocket; it has its arm in up to the elbow and beyond. That is the reality of Labor and taxes. That is the situation in which we find ourselves. This is a Government very much out of touch. We have a Prime Minister whose only agenda is not the future economic well-being of this country but a short-term electoral gain in the seats of Adelaide and Port Adelaide, and a short term political gain, as he perceived it, in the days leading up to the by-election in the seat of Oxley. He is trying to fool and deceive people into the belief that the good times are coming when in fact the economic situation in this country is of growing concern.

As a result of the build-up of expectations we now see people in the trade union movement such as Mr Kelty, the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, saying that they are looking forward to the biggest tax cuts in history. The dogs are barking. We had Mr Harrison on air this morning talking about what the trade union movement is prepared to take and the negotiating position that it will develop. We see differences in the trade union movement, with the Left in Sydney starting to run its own campaign. The reality is that with the build-up of expectation there will be a build-up which the Government will be unable to fulfil. The reality and the consequence of this build-up for wages policy is very considerable indeed. Of course, if the tax cuts do not fulfil expectations there is no doubt that there will be a push across the board for wage increases.

I contrast the prospect of that with what the Minister at the table, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris), will tell us is the Government's industrial policy, on the one hand, and its wages policy, on the other. With the second tier, the national wage case and the guidelines laid down for award restructuring we have seen some attempt to move from a situation in which there is an expectation of across the board increases on the basis of indexation to a more productivity-based system of wage calculation. There is no doubt that one of the severe consequences of the build-up of expectations by the Prime Minister in recent weeks in respect of wages policy is to deny the central element of what the Government calls its micro-reform agenda, that is, to move wages policy from a position of indexation or across the board payment to one which is focused on productivity and the capacity of individual firms and enterprises to pay.

This year there has been a 3 per cent payment and a $10 rise will follow six months later in a situation in which the Government has said, and the national wage case has said, people get the money now on the basis that they sit down and discuss with employers a basis for award restructuring which will provide some real productivity improvements for the economy. The Government is, therefore, essentially between a rock and a hard place because the Government, led by a Prime Minister whose short-term ambitions and short-term political strategy are the be all and end all, has placed itself in a situation in which, instead of focusing on what it has claimed to be its central objective, it has placed all the focus, all the public discussion, on the expectations of tax cuts next year.

It is no good the Minister for Industrial Relations saying, as he did yesterday on television when asked about the ramifications of the divisions between the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance, `Look, do not ask me a question on that. You know I do not answer questions like that'. That is no answer! The Minister is now in the Cabinet and the conflicts, the build-up of expectations, the personal conflict between the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, are eating away, eroding away what the Government claims to be its central policy.

SPEECH.PARA: How can members of the Opposition have the gall to come in here and try to lecture us and hector us about industrial relations policy? Firstly, they do not have one. Secondly, has anybody forgotten the seven dark years of Fraserism? Has anybody forgotten their abandonment of centralised wage fixing and the open slather they allowed to go forward in 1980-81, with a wages break-out that resulted in an enormous increase in unemployment in the year that followed? Has anybody forgotten that? No, they have not. Nobody has forgotten the fact that the man then at the helm in financial matters is the current Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). He was the Treasurer, and he is the man who authorised this matter of public importance to come forward today. No one has forgotten that. No one has forgotten that the Opposition parties have never had a wages policy. The system that they put forward in 1981 collapsed and wages blew out. Average weekly earnings grew by 17 per cent over the year to the September quarter 1982. The consumer price index blew out to 12.3 per cent over the same year. The coalition, the Liberal and National parties, those who present themselves now as having some modicum of competence in these matters, led us into the worst recession that this country has seen since the Great Depression of the 1930s.

What did they do when this great cherished proposal started to blow up in their faces? They panicked. They talked about decentralisation and they talked about deregulation in the labour market, and they swung back, in effect, to the most centralised form of wage system there is-a wage freeze. They imposed a wage freeze. It is important to remember this. Honourable members should take particular note because the same person, the Leader of the Opposition, the then Treasurer, was instrumental in bringing in the wage freeze. These are the same people who now feign a concern about family living standards. These same people feign an interest in what is happening to Australian families. It is well known from experience abroad that arbitrary freezes of that nature result in a wage blow-out after they are lifted. It is undoubtedly what would have happened if the coalition had still been in power. Wages would have blown out again and who knows what panic measures the coalition would have jumped to then-because they did not have the faintest idea what they were going to do. It was the old Micawber philosophy they have always followed, that maybe something will turn up. It is the only consistent policy that the conservatives in this country have ever had.

Fortunately, the country was spared that development because this Government came into office with an accord that had been worked out with the trade union movement in advance, and the accord was the exact antithesis of the confusion and panic that reigned under the coalition. The accord embodied a consensus approach. It has harnessed the contribution of the trade union movement and brought results in terms of industrial relations harmony and economic progress unparalleled in the history of this country.

Industrial disputation has fallen by more than half since those dark years of Fraserism, the years when the current Leader of the Opposition was the Treasurer. In our period of government we have created 1.14 million jobs. In our period of management the unemployment rate has fallen from over 10 per cent to 7 per cent. That is despite the large numbers of people who have been encouraged by general economic improvements to join the labour force. What is important is that under the accord process Labor has been able to handle difficulties that the coalition would have had no chance of handling. We provided an agreed and effective exit from the wage pause. The inflationary effects of the depreciation, stemming from the fall in Australia's terms of trade, were quarantined from the wage fixing system. The lot of the weakest and poorest of Australian families has been protected by real increases in pensions, benefits and initiatives, specifically the family allowance supplement. Most importantly, the job creation momentum has been kept up.

Let us remember that in the Opposition's last 12 months of government almost a quarter of a million Australians lost their jobs. Instead of pursuing that course, we have created 1.4 million new jobs. On average, Australia's employment growth has been over 3 per cent per year since we came to office-more than twice the average for the industrialised world. Far from confusion, the Government has produced the most effective wage fixing system in Australia's history. The strength of that wage fixing system and procedures lies in the accord process, which allows flexibility to adapt to new circumstances and to find effective solutions. The Opposition knows it could not do that. It frankly confessed that. It does not have a wages policy. It has only one policy, the Micawber policy-a `something might turn up' policy. It has one consistent theme in its approach to industrial relations, that is, anti-union division and confrontation.

No-one who has been in this chamber for a few years could forget the deliberate course of provocation pursued when the conservatives were on this side of the table. Industrial relations was an exercise in splitting and dividing the community, setting workers and trade unionists against management, creating division. The Opposition has not changed. It is talking about its industrial relations policy, if one could call it that-that ragbag of ideas. It has a very thin veneer of conciliation and mediation. That ragbag, that veneer, is all about fragmenting and destroying centralised wage fixing, destroying a national approach to wages policy in this country. What the Opposition wants is open slather. It says, `All businesses, one by one, will deal with their employees one by one'. Small business wants that kind of arrangement like it wants a hole in the head. Most small businesses do not have the resources, the skills or the people available to set up, one by one, industrial relations and mediation and consultation units. They depend upon the stability of a centralised system such as this Government has developed under the accord and under the structural efficiency principle brought down on 12 August. They depend on that to provide the overall umbrella of industrial relations for stability, equity and fairness and to provide also flexibility, so that there can be differences under that umbrella for particular locations, particular job situations and particular businesses.

The difference between us and the Opposition is stark. Only those with their heads in the sand, such as those opposite, can deny progress. Like the leopards that do not lose their spots, conservatives do not lose their spots. They have learnt nothing; they have forgotten nothing. That division and confrontation is that main theme of what they are on about. We will provide within the policy we are putting forward a flexibility for individual managements under the umbrella of the Industrial Relations Commission, to make the kinds of changes appropriate to their needs. Within that will come the improvements in productivity, the improvements in efficiency and the improvements in competitiveness that this country has to have for its products here and abroad. That is something the Opposition cannot grapple with. It has to fall back on the only thing it knows-division and confrontation.

It took the honourable member for Flinders a good 10 minutes of his speech to get anywhere near mentioning what he had put in the letter to the Speaker, the so-called matter of public importance. Let me ask the House: Just who does speak for the Opposition? Is it the honourable member for Bennelong? He was the principal architect of the disaster. No-one has forgotten those dark years of Fraserism-that pain and misery, that loss of a quarter of a million jobs. Maybe it is the other John-John Elliott-who speaks for the Opposition. One thing is very clear in this country: no matter how the Opposition seeks to paper it over and cover it up, the move to unseat the Leader of the Opposition is coolly, carefully and calculatingly designed to bring him down. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) put it best. He said, `It is like a carcass swinging in the breeze, hanging there dead and lifeless, but no-one is ready yet to cut it down'. I think it is probably John, the John that is not here. Honourable members could be excused for believing it is the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). After all, he is the shadow Treasurer; he had a say in this matter. On the other hand, it could be the Leader of the National Party, or rather Senator Stone.

We could go through half a dozen different names and eventually we would come to the honourable member for Flinders. It was quite evident from his contribution today that he is not having a very important role to play in all of this. Rather, to go along with the Melbourne Herald, he managed to present to us a cut and paste on the phoney issue of confusion allegedly on this side. I have rebutted that. I wish to say one thing: the honourable member for Flinders and the policies he is charged with espousing represent the mouth of divisiveness, of confrontation and fragmentation within this country. As I mentioned earlier, deregulation for small employers is destruction. Opposition policy means destruction of the progress and stability that Australian industry has gained from this Government. Let there be no doubt about it: the progress this Government has made is something that is unequalled in the history of this country. It is something that cannot be matched by those opposite, who have not even the slightest idea of how to approach it. We utterly reject the so-called matter of public importance that has been put forward by the honourable member for Flinders.

As the poster says, these two men are guilty-guilty of taking money from the pockets of millions of Australian taxpayers. We have seen the highest interest rates ever in this country and we have seen record bankruptcies, which are continuing. We have seen the largest current account deficit ever brought down, and a similar one will be brought down on Wednesday. We have seen the biggest blow-out in the overseas debt that I think any Western country has ever seen. We have seen a record decline in the value of the Australian dollar against overseas currencies, the highest tax rates ever laid down in this country, and the biggest public sector outlays ever. —They have been lied to.

—The honourable member for Gippsland makes a very accurate observation. The figures have finally come out. The average Australian family is $56 a week worse off. Five years ago it was $56 a week better off than it is today. The debt of every man, woman and child in this country to overseas countries is about $7,000. That is approaching $25,000 to $30,000 a family. We have reached the stage where today the interest and principal repayments to those overseas countries amount to the equivalent of about 65 per cent of our export income. That is absolutely abysmal. When the Treasurer gets up, as he did today in Question Time, and reels off how great things are and how he told people overseas how wonderful things are, I can only conclude that he was not in the finance sectors of West Germany, the United States of America and Japan: he was in cloud-cuckoo-land. Instead of the Treasurer skulking around the streets of Soho looking for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), as he told us-he was not there anyhow-he should have been talking to those people and learning what the situation is in the real world.

SPEECH.PARA: Overseas assessors are downgrading Australia's creditworthiness all the time. We have lost our AAA credit rating, which is down to a AA rating. I suppose a AA rating is appropriate because this Government has been on an incredible binge over the last five years. Whatever standard is used, the record is appalling. Let us take the average single income family with a couple of children. In March 1983 such a family paid $65 a week tax. As at July this year, a little over five years later, such a family was paying $119 a week. That is how much living standards have slipped.

Let us look at the home loan repayment of the average Australian. In March 1983 he was forking out an average of $350 a month. By July this year that figure had risen to $666 a month. It has almost doubled. According to those figures the only group in this country doing any good at all is those who construct caravans. In March 1983 the average person on unemployment benefit was unemployed for 35 weeks. Today the figure has soared to 60 weeks. The hopelessness of the unemployed has never been so great in this country. The pensioners and the veterans of this country have been ripped off and denied.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which world are you living in?

—People such as the alternative Treasurer from the far Left, who is babbling away in his seat, and those running this country are aspiring to do that. They still portray themselves as competent economic managers.
—They are out of touch.

—As the honourable member for Cowper says, they are out of touch. The National Media Liaison Service-that Goebbels-type propaganda unit which the Government set up and which is funded by taxpayers' money-runs to the press gallery and feeds it stories. The rat pack of the press gallery has been fawning on the sorts of figures that have been given to date. Those days are over. The press gallery is starting to wake up, as is the Australian public. The Government's spokesmen are at sixes and sevens: they are totally confused. They have built up an expectation in the community which they cannot deliver on. We have seen a classic example of that in recent weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the Oxley by-election the Prime Minister went around saying, `All is rosy. We have done it a bit hard for a few years, but from now on you will have tax cuts and wage rises and things will start to fall your way'. The Prime Minister would do and say anything for a vote. He would sell his soul for a vote. The very week after the by-election, which was the second biggest rebuff for any government in Australia's history, the Government changed its mind. The day before the Oxley by-election the Prime Minister said, `It is rather unrealistic to talk about no wage rises at all'. However, the very same day the Treasurer said, `Zero wage rises are still a possibility'. Senator Button and Senator Walsh tried to back him up by saying the same things. But their real master-the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU)-said via its President that such statements were totally unrealistic and that we would have a nil increase in wages next year. The ACTU Secretary, Bill Kelty, said there was no way that there would be a wage freeze. In recent days the Prime Minister has tried to back off and hose down the statements of expectation that he came out with only a week ago.

That is the situation with wages. Regarding taxes, the Treasurer virtually announced a short while ago that the upper level of tax will come down from 49c in the dollar to 39c in one hit. Virtually the same day the Prime Minister said that if it comes down at all it will be phased in. Again, Senator Button and Senator Walsh tried to correct those statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are out of touch with each other as well.

—As the honourable member for Cowper says, they are out of touch not only with the Australian people but also with each other. What summed it up better than anything else was a survey done by the Strategic Research International Group, which is a New York-based firm of financial analysts. That group surveyed 21 countries around the world and ranked each country on the basis of the fundamental economic trends in those countries. The survey was based on factors such as balance of payments, overseas debt and the domestic economic conditions applying to those countries. Where did Australia rate out of those 21 countries? We came last: absolutely stone motherless last. It was incredible. The Treasurer wonders why the people around Australia call him the undertaker! While countries such as Japan, West Germany and America were winning the gold medal, the silver medal and the bronze medal, it seems that the Australian Treasurer's medal should be fashioned out of the metal of rusty buckets. The press gallery and the Australian public are starting to wake up to it. Following the trend of the Adelaide by-election and the other by-elections, the Government will be swept from office at the next election.

The accord has held every time. Let me say to honourable members opposite that the accord will hold again. We will find a solution. That situation has been affirmed by the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and all of the economic spokesmen on our side.

It is interesting to contrast our approach to industrial relations with that of the Opposition. What does the Opposition want to do? In addition to throwing all of the people out of work, which I mentioned earlier, what did those opposite do in this country in their seven years in government between the Whitlam Government and the Hawke Government? They created an industrial relations climate that was poisonous. There was conflict every day. There was a huge increase in the number of days lost due to industrial disputes. They could not talk to the trade union movement; they could not work things out with the trade union movement. They could not get the unions together with the employers to work for the good of Australia. Their attitude was `We have to beat the workers over the head'.

It was very interesting to hear the comments of the new shadow Minister for Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). I could not work out whether he was saying that the Government must come out now and offer people a very big tax cut or whether he was saying, `Oh no, the Government should not offer people any tax cut at all because it would be irresponsible'. One could not figure out whether he was saying one thing or the other. Of course, the problem is that we never know where the Opposition stands on these matters. Members of the Opposition are all over the place. Members of the Opposition then say, `Because you cannot sort out this problem'-which I have explained we will be sorting out-`there will be some big problem in industrial relations'. There would be a big problem in industrial relations if, by some mischance, honourable members opposite ever got into government and instituted the kinds of anti-union and anti-worker policies which have been instituted in places like the United Kingdom and which have led to mass unemployment and mass industrial disruption.

We have to rebuild and restructure this economy. We have a lot of difficult decisions to make-decisions of the kind which the Opposition never made in its seven years of Government. We are working on that process. Those difficult decisions sometimes hurt some people. However, we have put into place packages of assistance for people. We have put into place the family assistance scheme. We have put into place packages to assist people who are unemployed for a short time as a result of industry restructuring. We have put into place training and retraining programs. We are looking positively at all aspects of this matter. What do we have from the Opposition? Do we have any concrete suggestions? No, all we have is a carping attitude on the part of the Opposition which jumps on the bandwagon and says, `Look, there appears to be some difference between what one Minister says and what another Minister says, so we will go out and claim that there is a huge problem between the Government and the trade union movement'. The economic strategy of this Government has been, in many ways, unique in the sense that it has achieved, through an incomes policy and an agreement with the union movement, the creation of jobs. This has enabled us to overcome the kinds of problems that many countries have witnessed. We need to continue with that general strategy to create even more jobs and to develop this country further. This is the only way to go, not the negative approach as put forward by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: That amendments 1 to 9 be agreed to.

I want to explain the background to what the Senate has proposed and why the Government considers that the amendments should be accepted. It may be helpful to identify the source of the amendments. In this group of nine amendments there are seven Government amendments and two Australian Democrat amendments. Broadly described, the Government amendments are non-controversial, technical and designed to improve the operation of the legislation. They were accepted by the Senate without any opposition. Government amendments (1) to (3) are designed to improve the operation of clause 121. This clause enables the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to make awards in areas of Commonwealth and Territory employment where difficulties might otherwise exist as a result of the operation of State or Territory legislation. Amendment (4) broadens the range of industry consultative councils under clause 133 in which members of the new Commission can participate.

Amendments (5) and (6) are amendments moved by the Australian Democrats and supported by the Opposition. Clause 189 was amended by reducing the minimum membership requirement for federally registered unions from 3,000 to 1,000. Clause 197, which provides for the review, after three years, of the continued registration of unions with fewer than minimum membership, was consequentially amended.

The Government is disappointed that the Democrats were unable to accept the Government's proposals. The minimum membership requirement is one of a number of interrelated proposals, which are designed to encourage the restructuring of federally registered unions in a way which complements and strengthens the significant progress towards achieving far greater efficiency in Australia's industries and enterprises. Undoubtedly the creation of fewer and better resourced unions, particularly through amalgamations, where a community of interest exists between the participants, will simplify and accelerate the essential processes of award restructuring, the redesigning of work without rigid job demarcations and the establishment of a multiskilled work force. Reducing the threshold membership requirement for registration will impair the speed with which those objectives can be reached. Even so, the Government is prepared to accept the amendment to avoid delays in achieving the other significant reforms under the Bill.

Amendments (7) and (8) relate to clause 197. The clause, which concerns elections in registered organisations, is amended to clarify its operation in relation to the correction of defects in the nomination of candidates for election. Amendment (9) deals with the eligibility for membership provision, clause 261. The provision is amended to clarify its operation and to avoid any unintended narrowing of the range of persons who have an enforceable right to be admitted to an organisation with appropriate coverage of their work. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall confine any remarks to those amendments relating to the size of unions. The Government's original proposition was a figure of 3,000, and the Senate has reduced that to 1,000. The Opposition's view is that we should not prescribe arbitrarily any figure at all, and our preferred position was simply to delete the arbitrary limit in the Government's proposed legislation. For all the comments of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris), the fact is that our policy is not anti-union at all. He needs to understand the focus of our industrial relations policy, which is aimed at encouraging direct negotiations between employers and employees. It is not good enough just to say that big is beautiful, which is the Government's position in respect of the Industrial Relations Bill. The fact is that the size of a particular union ought to be a function of the capacity of that group to represent the interests of all of the union membership.

SPEECH.PARA: I note the Government's constant claims that the whole Bill represents one of the great reforms of industrial relations, which is absolute nonsense-and I am glad that the former Minister is in the House. It is just typical gross exaggeration by the Government. I think there is proper concern that bigger unions simply mean, in some circumstances, more power for union bureaucrats. Of course, that is not in the interests of a sensible wages policy, let alone the interests of union members. Clearly there are some problems in the area of the size of unions. Demarcation disputes would be one area. I think honourable members are aware of others, such as the difficulty of having unions based on occupation rather than industry or enterprise, which would encourage the rapid flow of wage adjustments from one part of the economy to other parts.

The problem is not that unions are too small. A small union, in which all the members have a close community of interest, may in fact be able to represent its members more effectively than a large bureaucratic organisation which has to look after the interests of employees in widely diverging industries or enterprises. In any case, it should be for the members to decide whether their union is effectively representing their interests.

This Government loves to talk about democracy. But what about the rights of members to make decisions about the sort of entity which will represent their interests? Why does this Government deny union members the right to make those basic decisions? Why does this Government reckon it can sit in Canberra and dictate how people should organise their affairs? One of the great problems that we have in wages policy is the very simple fact that this Government likes to give support to union bureaucrats against the interests of union members.

Our principle is very simple: we acknowledge that people have a right to associate. Freedom of association is a basic principle in this society. We also want to see economic structures built up which properly reflect the demands of the membership. Whilst we will support this proposal, as it is a compromise and is something better than the 3,000 that the Government was originally proposing, it would be better if the Government had accepted the great strength of the attitude which I have expressed and which has been put in the Senate. This Bill makes it difficult-it actually puts barriers in the way-for union members to establish unions to represent their interests better. It is highly doubtful that this Bill will affect the number of demarcation disputes because it is often the case, as recent studies have shown, that it is the big unions that get into demarcation disputes rather than the small ones.

Big is not beautiful. In fact, the arbitrary establishment of limits for unions is contrary to the interests of members and contrary to the interests that we all have in having an economic, wages and union structure which best serves the interests of those people that those unions are established to serve-that is, the members. That is the position of the Opposition. We regret that the Government has not seen fit to enact legislation which would serve the interests of union members.

SPEECH.PARA: I was fascinated to grasp that from the comments of the honourable member for Flinders. It is all just too hard. What we have seen here is a little political opportunism masquerading as an industrial relations policy. To talk about a business by business set of industrial relations where each business which has two, 10 or 12 employees will have its own industrial relations award arrangements with those two, 10 or 20 employees-and so it will go down the scale-is a multiplicity of arrangements and agreements that can only result in division, fragmentation and instability. Put very succinctly, it provides the opportunity, the freedom, for the very strong to exploit the weak under the pretence of giving individual rights to workers. Put in that way it is an absolute nonsense. The Opposition should be honest about it and come clean.

This proposal provides the opportunity to exploit the weak; it provides the freedom to do sweetheart deals which will result in the passing on of costs to the rest of the community; it provides the freedom to fuel inflation; it provides the freedom to undermine national economic policy-in fact, it is the abandonment of national economic policy-it would provide the opportunity for a conservative government to abandon financial responsibility for economic policy and just to walk away and leave it by saying, `This is case by case. Each of these companies, partnerships and little businesses will deal with their own employees. We don't have any sort of overall national wage policy'. In essence, it is a rerun of what the conservatives have always done-walk away from the tough challenges. Very clearly, it provides the prescription for industrial anarchy. To have that masquerade as something that is good for industrial trade unionists and to purport that it represents an improvement for individual trade unions is, in the Government's view, the ultimate in hypocrisy.

I marvel at the fact that after all these years the Opposition still cannot bring itself to have a credible, comprehensive industrial relations policy. Is the honourable member for Flinders really saying to the Committee that in a nation such as West Germany-one of the most successful economies in the world since World War II, with about 16 unions in a population of some 60 million-this situation does not work, that it is far better to have what we have here which is 330-odd unions in a work force of about 7 1/2 million? Is he saying that 330 unions are not enough and that we should have more; that we should have one by one arrangements for the hundreds of thousands of individual businesses in this country and that they should each have their own set of arrangements? That should be seen for the idiocy that it is. It is a prescription for irresponsibility and industrial anarchy.

I wish the Opposition would think a bit more deeply about it. It purports to represent the interests of business but business is not with it on this one; industry is not with it on this one-it is on its Pat Malone with this one. No matter what the facts are and no matter what is appropriate to industry needs, it does not matter. The Opposition is looking for a little bit of political opportunism so that it can masquerade as representing the interest of individuals. Were that policy to be put into effect, heaven help the individuals. The Opposition is out of step with industry's needs, with community's needs, and with the rest of the industrial world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever we needed evidence of the Government's big brother approach, that little episode from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) surely should put the cap on what we have been saying. A very comprehensive and radical policy has been presented by the Opposition and put before industry people around the country. As far as I know, it has obtained near unanimous, if not unanimous, support. One of the basic tenets of that policy is that there shall be no limit on the number of people who shall comprise a union. The first amendment we are dealing with, which is covered by 1 to 9 in the schedule, promises to do little to improve the recipe for continuing centralised control of industrial matters which the unamended Industrial Relations Bill represented.

SPEECH.PARA: For most of this century, the Australian work force has been chained by the centralised industrial relations system which has created unemployment, reduced the incentive for productivity and hard work, and has undermined the competitiveness of all Australian businesses to some large or lesser extent. This Industrial Relations Bill is intended to entrench further that system. It blatantly protects the interests of those already dependent on the system who have been aptly described as the industrial relations club. The amendments which have been proposed by the Senate-particularly amendments 5 and 6-raise further the question of freedom which plagued the Industrial Relations Bill when it was before the House in May. Honourable members will also recall that it was brutally guillotined through this place. What is the hurry? Five months later we are debating it again but the Government would not let us debate the merits of what is a very important Bill in terms of the social fabric of this country as well as the economy.

One of the most consistently offensive aspects of the conciliation and arbitration system, as it is now constituted, has been its denial of freedom of association through the enforcement of real and de facto compulsory trade union membership, the registration of monopoly unions, and the real and de facto preference for trade union members. This amendment, which will reduce the minimum membership requirement for registration of a trade union from 3,000 members to 1,000 members, was introduced by the Australian Democrats. Of course, it effectively demonstrates the appalling double standards of that political party. All Australians should know that the Democrats would not support Opposition amendments to remove the preference clauses in this Bill which effectively enforce compulsory trade union membership.

While members of the Opposition will not oppose this amendment, we do so only because it is not as bad as the even more draconian proposal of the Government in the unamended legislation. Even with this amendment, this Bill will infringe those freedoms of voluntary association which the legislation of this Parliament should uphold. The Minister rabbited on for a while but he overlooks the fact that the Government is prepared to hide behind the foreign affairs powers when it cannot get its way with the States. It will rely on conventions and treaties that it has ratified in this country. But when it comes to the labour market, regulation of trade unions and compulsory trade unionism, and the principle of freedom of association, it ignores three international conventions which it has already ratified. The first is article 20 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which provides:
Everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association.
It also provides:
No-one may be compelled to belong to an association.
Incidentally, that was ratified by the Government. Article 2 of the International Labour Organisation Convention Concerning Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise provides:

Workers and employers, without distinction whatsoever, shall have the right to establish and, subject only to the rules of the organisation concerned, to join organisations of their own choosing without previous authorisation.
This legislation contravenes that international treaty also. Further, article 22 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights states:
Everyone shall have the right to freedom of association with others. . .
By stipulating a minimum membership of 1,000 before a trade union can become registered, we will be as a country in breach of all those international conventions and treaties which we have ratified.

It should be made clear that in proposing this amendment the Australian Democrats are accepting the principles on which the Government has founded its corporatist approach to industrial relations. Far from keeping anyone honest, the Democrats have accepted the arguments of narrow vested interests-and, of course, the Labor Government-to entrench the essential corruption of the Australian industrial relations system, which precludes individuals looking after their own affairs and instead establishes monopoly coverage of trades and industries by existing unions. The Government has gone out of its way to assist the bureaucrats of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) in furthering a policy of enforcing the amalgamation of trade unions to create a few large, powerful, wealthy organisations which will be unresponsive to their members and which will exclude any competition for membership between unions. It is another element of the approach of this Government towards big business, big unions and big government.

This amendment will slightly reduce the force of that push for amalgamation, by allowing a number of existing small-but not the smallest-unions to continue to be registered. The Australian Labor Party has never had much confidence in the ability of individual union members, whom it considers to be its supporters, to make decisions for themselves. It treats its supporters with contempt. That is one reason why so many trade union members have always supported the Liberal Party of Australia. Of course, that is unarguable because we would not get the percentage vote we do had they not supported us in the past.

The clause, as amended, will still seek to enforce amalgamation and continue that tradition of which I have just spoken. The Government suggests that Australia has too many unions for them to service all their members' interests effectively, but it does not trust union members enough to think that they might realise this for themselves and act to change things on their own initiative. Oh, no; we have to put something in over the top. The reality that the Government and the ACTU do not want to acknowledge is that when given the opportunity some people like the chance to join small unions. They do not want big unions. There is an understandable antipathy towards the larger bureaucratic unions which demand so much from their members to support the officials, but offer few benefits to those who actually work in industry. The proposals for enterprise-based unions which the coalition favours are both economically efficient and popular amongst many of those who realise that on most issues there is no divergence between their interests as workers and those of the firm for which they work.

The Labor Party and the trade union movement are responsible for fostering this false belief, this myth, that individual employees and employers are, in some way, fundamentally opposed. In promoting this myth, they are acting out of blatant self-interest and working against the welfare of union members. Indeed, in reality, there is greater competition between employees in competing firms than between employee and employer in the same firm. If the economies of scale in larger unions are nearly as great as this Hawke-Keating Government suggests, acting as it does as the mouthpiece of the ACTU, genuine freedom of association would achieve the goals of those who want larger unions anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say something about the amendment in respect of union subscriptions and dues. It was an initiative of the Opposition. I compliment senators in the other place for raising this matter, in particular Senator Chaney and Senator Chapman. I have a couple of examples involving local constituents. SPEECH.PARA: This amendment prevents unreasonable demands by unions in that situation where a person has actually left his occupation and moved on to another position. This is a measure which, apart from having very considerable practical consequences for probably tens of thousands of union members, is rather symbolic of the difference between the Opposition and the Government. The fact of the matter is that this was an Opposition initiative. It is something that this Government should have undertaken more willingly than it did. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has already been said, this amendment concerns the liability of people to pay the membership fees of registered organisations such as trade unions. It is essential to uphold some degree of fair practice for those unfortunate people who have little choice but to become members of trade unions, the alternative being to do without a job. At present many jobs require union membership before they can be taken up because of the requirement that trade union members should be granted preference over those who have chosen not to be union members. Supposedly, this is in the interests of industrial harmony. This means that the tyranny of those who would infringe the rights of others is given legal sanction to preserve some kind of unjust peace with the belief of the trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone who doubts that compulsory trade union membership is a reality in Australia should observe what goes on on major, and not so major, building sites in our capital cities and around the country. Individuals who have little choice but to join a trade union or go jobless have few protections under this Industrial Relations Bill, which we are seeking to amend. They are constantly assaulted by astounding requirements for action on the part of what should be voluntary associations independent of direct government control. Clearly, this is not the case.

This legislation involves detailed government intervention in the affairs of trade unions dealing with membership, registration, the rules of unions, conduct of elections, amalgamations, accounts and record keeping. Why does the trade union movement not cry out at the intervention of government in its affairs? The answer is simple: the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) has effectively designed the provisions which we are considering about the conduct of unions. It is not the Government but the ACTU which controls the industrial legislation which comes before this chamber. It is not surprising, therefore, that the provisions of the Industrial Relations Bill favour the organisational operation of the trade unions rather than the individuals who make up the membership. This amendment will help to rectify one of the those many presumptions in favour of the big and powerful organisations and, therefore, against the individual.

This Labor Government, the Hawke-Keating Government-or is it the Keating-Hawke Government?-has proposed a system under which people could be liable to pay membership dues to unions even though they are not eligible to be members of those unions. If a member leaves employment in an industry which is not covered by the union of which he or she is a member, he or she will no longer be eligible for membership of that union. It is straightforward. A member can resign from a union but notice must be given in writing if that person is no longer eligible for membership. If notice is not received in writing, under clause 264 (3) of the Bill the association, meaning the union in this context, is entitled to sue for recovery of membership dues over the period after the individual has ceased to be eligible for membership.

The purpose of this amendment is to allow a defence in recovery action over membership dues on the basis that the defendant was not eligible to be a member of the association or union in question. The amendment is perfectly reasonable. It does just a little to right the balance between the individual and the centralised bureaucratic organisation. When people who want to work are not free to choose whether they want to be a member of a union, they should at least be free of the burden of those unions when they cease to work.
