TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition amendment is relatively minor in its direct implications because it relates only to the Northern Territory. However, it demonstrates principles relevant to the wider impact of the Industrial Relations Bill. The amendment will allow the continued existence of certain autonomous tribunals in the Northern Territory which have handled particular industrial matters. Without this amendment the Industrial Relations Commission would be able to hear and arbitrate in regard to certain matters despite the continued existence of local authorities specifically for the purpose. This raises questions about jurisdiction and the centralisation of power which the Industrial Relations Bill furthers. The expanded role of the Commonwealth's powers in industrial matters has been aided by recent decisions of the High Court of Australia as well as the legislative activity of the Hawke-Keating Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, in proposing this legislation, has suggested that the centralisation of proceedings will allow matters to be dealt with `more speedily, more informally and more cheaply'. Not only is this contrary to the lessons of history and our experience with the old Conciliation and Arbitration Commission-which, I might add, was not noted for its speed and efficiency in solving problems, as anyone who was waiting to fly with Ansett Airlines of Australia a couple of days ago would well know-but it is laughable when it is examined in the context of this amendment, the non-acceptance of which could result in the huge expense and inconvenience of people travelling to and from Melbourne instead of using local resources and people with a knowledge of local industry and conditions.

The example of the Northern Territory illustrates the problems of a centralised industrial relations system in a large country such as Australia. The Federal system is the means by which Australia has traditionally solved its problems of government, although in industrial relations excessive regulation by State governments is as destructive as excessive Federal regulation. That circumstance is compounded by the attempts of Federal Labor governments to expand their power over industrial matters, including the determination of wages.

The Industrial Relations Bill sets up procedures for the Industrial Commission to have power in matters affecting the States, and presumably the Territories as well, where the States refer matters to the Commission. The procedure established sounds suspiciously like that for the interchange of powers which was rejected by the Australian people at the referendum in 1984. By mutual agreement the State industrial authorities will be able to act as agents for this newly created industrial commission and vice versa.

I can see this cooperative procedure being the subject of controversy in the future as the Federal Commission tries to take over State authorities and, given the weight of money and support that it can get from the Federal Government, that takeover is almost inevitable. If we are not witnessing the beginning of the death of the State conciliation and arbitration apparatus I will be very surprised. If this sounds a little far-fetched, I remind members of the Australian Securities Commission Bill, which was debated recently and which would achieve exactly what the cooperative scheme which is presently operating in connection with company law has achieved.

Whenever the division of powers between the Federal and State government becomes blurred, for whatever reason, there is pressure for the potential conflict to be resolved. Too often it has been resolved in favour of the Commonwealth and that is not accidental, nor was it unforeseen at the time that the legislation we are discussing today was introduced. It is important to avoid any unnecessary attempt to confuse the existing division of powers between Federal and State authorities. I suggest this will confuse, at least for a short time, the differences and the sharing of powers with State authorities and, as I have already said, I think we will see them disappear like the dinosaurs. Their effectiveness will disappear, even if they do not physically disappear.

This amendment will maintain the autonomy of independent industrial tribunals in the Northern Territory and should therefore be supported as helping to preserve a Federal division of powers. I have no problem with that; in fact, it is entirely consistent with the argument I have been advancing. That does not imply support for the rest of the legislation. I simply report that many of these matters could have been dealt with-perhaps some of these amendments could have been proposed and passed in this chamber-had not the guillotine been applied last May, or whenever it was. We had about half an hour to discuss what is fundamental legislation. We have it back some five months later, which makes a mockery of the procedure adopted by the Government in the management of the House at the time. We could all have had a fair go. We might have legislated better in this chamber instead of doing as we so often do and that is to subcontract our legislative rights to our colleagues across Members' Hall. We are fast becoming recognised as simply a political chamber rather than a legislative House of this Parliament.

I have raised this matter before and I suspect I will continue to raise it. I know honourable members on the other side feel exactly the same way and I see the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) nodding his head in agreement. It is something which is very disturbing. We are not all bush lawyers but we can make legislation better, even legislation with which we do not agree. We can remove some of the bugs if we are given the time and the opportunity in this chamber. So with that little commercial I shall resume my seat, but I enjoin the Government to consider making this chamber more legislative in its work. Perhaps then we will all be better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the brief time allowed to talk on estimates in this place-and I must say that I have total sympathy with the views expressed by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) in the previous debate-there are many aspects of this portfolio which I think should be better examined here, and in the complex of our proceedings there were procedures once which enabled a debate in this place to occur in much the same way as it does in the other place. SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to talk about a number of aspects of the trade responsibilities within this portfolio, first because I am quite concerned that the Government and, in particular, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), apparently have no idea at all of what is happening to the Australian economy. The basis of my concern in respect of the departmental structures lies in the fact that four departments are responsible for trade at a time when our trade and our current account are absolutely critical for the well-being of this nation. There is no doubt that the figures demonstrate that Australia has fallen over the last few years from eighth to twenty-third place as an exporter. We know that our share of global exports has fallen from 2 per cent to 0.9 per cent, and with that has come a slide in our per capita income. Some years ago Australia enjoyed the fifth highest per capita income in the world. Today it has slipped to nineteenth.

It is of worry to me that in addressing the trade component of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade there is an inability to really address the other three components. Not only do we have within this Department the Minister for Trade Negotiations but we have a separate department altogether, the ministry of Primary Industries and Energy, and we have another department, the department responsible for Austrade, which is promoting Australian trade, in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. I regard it as totally unsatisfactory that, in dealing with the most critical part of Australia's economy, in looking at our balance of payments and in looking forward to where we might be able to take steps to redress some of the difficulties in our current account and external debt position, we have four departments and, hence, four departmental estimates that should be addressed.

The idea of super-departments has failed abysmally as the total turmoil within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade represents. Again within that it is very hard to address the subject, although, to my mind, that is probably one of the most fundamental of all the administrative challenges that the Hawke Administration faces, and absolutely nothing has been done about it. The former Minister has moved on to higher things and returned from his jaunt abroad. There is now a new Minister whose attitudes and views concern me, but again I do not want to address them today. There has been a change in the permanent head of the Department and I believe the deputy permanent head is presumably about to be moved out of the Department because the new Minister does not get on with him. If that is so, I think it is very regrettable. I am concerned about the administrative complexity of a department which has these overlays.

In the detail of the estimates, I am equally concerned about where we are going in the Uruguay Round, the multilateral trade negotiations. It is important for Australia to succeed, but, like the Minister for Trade Negotiations, who, on his return, expressed some pessimism, I too am pessimistic, because I am concerned that the Government has done so little to try to ensure that we initiate talks in the bilateral field-for example, taking up with the United States of America the opportunities that Mr Yeutter endeavoured to put to us about the time the Canadians were discussing free trade access with the Americans. It is not that we necessarily might want to take up the offer, but at least it gives us some bargaining coin, and this Government has passed it by.

I am concerned, however, that a lot of other key economic issues need to be addressed. Perhaps the most important is the fact that we progressively are losing our credibility as a reliable supplier. I have a headline here from the Daily Commercial News: `Australia regarded as an unreliable supplier'-and we all know that there are so many areas in which that is apparent. Perhaps there is none more so than what happened in the port of Melbourne at the weekend. I find it incredible that the Government has not even been prepared to try to assist the HMS Ark Royal to dock in weather conditions which were obviously very difficult, and I feel that the nature of the Government's behaviour in relation to Port Melbourne at the weekend illustrates the whole problem in the trade field. The Government is not prepared to take our international responsibilities seriously and it does not understand that to succeed in the Uruguay Round or to succeed in our bilateral negotiations we must have a reputation as a reliable exporter and a country that can be trusted. How can one trust a government that is not even prepared to assist one of its closest allies and to allow an invited naval warship to dock in the port of Melbourne? What has happened is that the Socialist Left of the Victorian Government has taken it over. I introduced a piece of legislation in 1982, the Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill. If that piece of legislation had been reintroduced, it would have given the Hawke Government an opportunity to ensure that HMS Ark Royal was berthed. But the Government is concerned neither with that nor with the docking of HMS Edinburgh. Neither in defence matters nor in the trade and commercial area is the Government really worried about Australia's declining reputation.

Nothing really brings our general reputation out more than the absolute disaster on the waterfront, and no analysis of the estimates of this Department would be really complete without referring to a number of the problems. We know that the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report has talked about the cost of transporting Australia's exports and imports and has talked about potential savings of more than $2 billion from transport reform, or nearly 20 per cent of the cost of the total value of goods exported. That equally would be supplanted if we could look at our own coastal shipping arrangements. Of that $2 billion the IAC says that around $200m relates to Australian flag shipping covering both coastal shipping and trans-Tasman shipping, $300m relates to international liner shipping, $700m relates to land transport of bulk commodities, particularly rail freight, and $850m relates to the ports and waterfront.

We have heard a little about the comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the Business Council of Australia presentation of the export awards the other day, and the Prime Minister said how important it was. He talked about the difficulties that he saw and he picked up the figures that we have all been commenting on, such as the fact that apparently to transship milk powder from Taiwan to Tasmania costs $72 a tonne, but it costs $82 a tonne from Tasmania to Melbourne. The Australian Newsprint Mills says that the cost of shipping newsprint from a major European port to London was less than $50 a tonne whereas it is double that amount to ship it the same distance from Hobart to Sydney.

We have any number of statistics on imports, too. In relation to salt, for example, Australia is an efficient exporter of salt to the Pacific basin but the high cost of shipping it around the coast makes it cheaper for some users to buy salt from Mexico. In Weipa in north Queensland we mine a material called kaolin which is used to produce coated paper which we export to Europe, but the major Australian user of kaolin, Associated Pulp and Paper Mills in Tasmania, is importing it because it costs so much more to use the Australian product. Perhaps the paradox of all is the Adelaide Brighton Cement company, which imports cement clinker from Japan for use in Darwin because it is too dear to bring it up from its own cement plant in Adelaide.

That is an absolute disaster and there is nothing in these estimates that addresses this problem that the Prime Minister so blithely referred to. The Prime Minister is doing nothing about it and does not intend to do anything about it. Of course he will tut and tut and tell the business world how serious the problem is, but the reality is that it all emerged in the Daily Commercial News of 13 October this week when Tas Bull, the General Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, said that he had had a call from the great man and the great man had said to him, `Don't worry, Tas, all is okay'. He said that the radio presentation had `distorted' what the Prime Minister had really meant. The report stated:
. . . after viewing a copy of Mr Hawke's address and then speaking to him personally, Mr Bull felt there was no change in the Government's previously stated policy on the waterfront.

This is disastrous. There is an enormous problem. Those of us who have been flying in and out of Sydney have seen the container ships off the port of Sydney not being discharged. We have seen container ships off the port of Sydney not being discharged. We know of the 16,000 containers held up on our wharves. We know about all the problems. We know about the decline in statistics. We know about the problems in bulk commodities. I have not even had time to refer to the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport. We know that something has to be done about it.

Unless the Government faces up to the fact that it cannot accept that there will be no change in its previously stated policy on the waterfront, our continued bad reputation abroad will continue. This is an important area. These estimates do not address the problem. The administrative responsibility is split into four. I suggest that the Government start taking trade and commerce seriously. If we do not we will continue to slip down the Argentinean road which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister seem so intent on thrusting upon us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For many years the main objective of Australian foreign policy and strategy has been to preserve the peace and to prevent the expanding presence and influence of communist nations in the south-west Pacific region. The east Asian-western Pacific region remains a major theatre of confrontation between the free world and the Soviet Union, and political, military and economic rivalry will increase in the years to come. For decades the long term goal of the Soviet Union has been to weaken dominant free world influence in the south-west Pacific region. Over the past few years the Soviet Union has deployed space monitoring and intelligence gathering vessels to the South Pacific. Indeed, the importance of the South Pacific for control of space is one of the reasons why the Soviet Union has in recent years attempted to establish footholds among the nations of the South Pacific.

SPEECH.PARA: I will speak in this debate about one major issue of concern involving Australia's foreign policy and trade. Some months ago the Soviet Union expressed interest in offering Australia a long term wheat agreement worth more than $100m a year in exchange for a deal involving port access for fishing vessels and landing rights for the Soviet airline, Aeroflot, for crew changes. If approved, the deal would permit port access for up to 50 Soviet fishing vessels which regularly ply the Southern Ocean off Australia and up to 9,000 fishermen a year operating through Australia. It would also include a joint scientific venture, with five Soviet research ships and Australian observers assessing the marine resources in Australian waters. In the Australian of 7 July 1988 a Deputy Prime Minister of the Soviet Union, Mr Vladimir Kamentsev, was reported to have `guaranteed there would be no spying by the 50 fishing boats the Soviets want to be allowed to use Australian ports'. Mr Kamentsev was also reported to have said that `no Soviet ship was involved in spying or equipped with nuclear bombs as some superman spies'. Only a grown-up mug would accept these statements as having any basis in reality. It is my belief that to allow the Soviet fishing fleet access to Australian ports without the most stringent security safeguards could jeopardise national security.

Let me briefly examine some aspects of the activities of the Soviet fishing fleet. The Soviet Union operates the world's largest fishing fleet, with almost eight million gross registered tonnes. The Soviets exploit fishing grounds throughout the world's oceans with large flotillas of ships. As I have already stated, there are about 50 ships fishing in waters near Australia. The flotillas are usually self-contained communities capable of providing their own repairs, supplies and provisions through auxiliary ships deployed with the fishing units. On occasions these auxiliaries support naval activities, although their primary role is commercial. All fishing fleet officers hold reserve commissions in the Soviet Navy, so there is a natural military involvement in all levels of management.

Fishing vessels are increasing their communications potential, with more and more units being configured with modern satellite communications facilities. This would contribute to real time surveillance and intelligence collection capability should these vessels be tasked with this mission. It would not be unusual for KGB-GRU agents to be assigned to fishing fleets for the purpose of human intelligence collection should the Soviets be allowed to call at Australian ports. I have no doubt that intelligence gathering is a major subsidiary motive in Soviet fishing activity overseas, as shown by its targets and techniques. The Soviets have also made special efforts to develop cooperation with nations strategically located or close to important international shipping lanes and straits.

Since the mid-1970s the Soviet Union has approached a number of South Pacific island nations for access to fisheries. The Russians approached Papua New Guinea for a fishing agreement in 1986 but the then Prime Minister said in February 1987 that, while he did not object to the Soviet presence in the Pacific region, he did not intend to invite the Soviet Union to fish around Papua New Guinea. Western Samoa banned Soviet fishing vessels from her ports and territorial waters in 1985. Tonga allowed a Soviet vessel to research tuna in 1980 but rejected a Soviet request to survey Tongan waters in 1984. In August 1982 Fiji refused a Soviet request for access to Fiji's 200-mile zone. Fiji's ports were closed to Soviet vessels in mid-1982, when the Government said that the Soviet Union had tried to interfere in Fiji's general election. However, cruise ships were admitted again from mid-1986. In 1985 the Solomon Islands and Tuvalu both rejected Soviet approaches for fishing rights in their exclusive economic zones. In 1985 the Soviet Union agreed to pay Kiribati $1.5m for a one-year fishing agreement allowing 16 Soviet trawlers to fish within its exclusive economic zone. Kiribati did not permit Soviet boats within her 12-mile territorial waters and denied them port facilities. In October 1986 Kiribati let the agreement lapse because the Soviets wanted to pay a smaller licence fee and to transfer fish to a mother ship inside Kiribati's territorial waters.

In January 1987 Vanuatu signed a one-year agreement with the Soviet Union for which it received $1.5m in exchange for permitting eight Soviet vessels to catch tuna in its exclusive economic zone. The Soviets are thus paying more per vessel to fish inside Vanuatu's poorer fishing grounds than they did in those of Kiribati. Those Soviet boats are now allowed access to Vanuatu's ports to purchase supplies and make repairs. The agreement provided for discussions on landing rights for the Soviet airline, Aeroflot, to replace fishing crews. However, the airport at Port Vila cannot at present handle long range aircraft but may do so after a $5m refit about to be carried out.

During his visit to Australia, Soviet Deputy Prime Minister Kamentsev also claimed that the Soviet Union already had long term fishing agreements with France and the United States. It is true that the United States has a fishing agreement with the Soviet Union. However, in the agreement signed this year the United States Government reduced the number of ports that Soviet vessels may visit and it does not allow charter flights to bring crew members into US airports. These restrictions serve to reduce the chance for the Soviet Union to violate the terms of the fishing agreement. Any increase in the Soviet presence in Australia will require, as it does in the United States, increased government counter-intelligence capability to ensure that the Soviets do not abuse the terms under which they are admitted. It is interesting that at a time when the United States has reduced the number of ports to which Soviet fishing vessels have access, Australia is asked to open its ports to the Soviets.

Proponents of an Australia-Soviet fishing deal point to the US-Soviet fishing agreement as an excuse for justifying a fishing deal between Australia and the Soviet Union. But even if one of the results of an Australia-Soviet fishing deal is to open a new window in Australia for Soviet spying on Australian and allied defence facilities, on that ground alone I believe it would be an act of foolishness to conclude an Australia-Soviet Union fishing agreement. Even if Australia secured a broad economic package as part of a proposed fishing agreement, possibly including business joint ventures in Australia and in the Soviet Union, that in itself cannot justify an Australia-Soviet fishing agreement which would allow Soviet fishing boats access to Australian ports. It would be a pathetically naive person who would trust assurances given by the Soviet Deputy Prime Minister about not using the port access facilities for spying. It is laughable to suggest that the Soviets have been punctilious in living up to their undertakings thus far in the south-west Pacific. A recent British analysis of Soviet fishing deals around the world paints a sorry picture of espionage, electronic spying capacity, broken commercial undertakings and aggressive fishing methods that have seriously depleted fishing resources. High-handed Soviet behaviour has outraged many regional fishing industries.

To his credit, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been strongly sceptical of the Soviets' motives in seeking fishing and other deals in the Southern Pacific region. In the Age of 9 March 1987 the Prime Minister said:
I find it difficult, on the basis of Soviet activities around the world over the last couple of decades, to accept that they would limit their interests to purely fishing.

I have no doubt that the vast majority of Australian people fervently endorse this statement for its eminent good sense and national responsibility. The Prime Minister has been totally consistent in his opposition to fishing deals with the Soviet Union involving port access for Soviet ships. Australia has encouraged a number of Pacific island nations not to enter fishing agreements with the Soviet Union. It has prevailed upon three Australian States-Tasmania, Victoria and Western Australia-not to fall for the Soviet fishing deal bait. Who could ever forget the fervour with which the Soviets pursued their 1985 proposals for a floating dry dock off Western Australia? Above all, I fear claims that Australian counterespionage agencies can cope with any increased security dangers are about as credible as Mr Kamentsev's guarantee that none of the Soviet Union's fishing operations is involved in spying. Australians can take comfort in the knowledge that the Australian Prime Minister is standing ready to guarantee the integrity of the Australian security system and to preserve our alliance fully with the United States of America.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree almost entirely with what the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) has just said. My only qualification would be in the weight that he places upon the good sense of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when it comes to dealing with the Soviet Union. The Prime Minister has expressed concern, but it is strange that at the time the Prime Minister expresses concern his Government, apparently, is presently in negotiations with the Soviet Union over just the kind of fishing deal that has been described by the honourable member. There has been, of course, a change in the conduct of foreign policy in this country. Mr Hayden has decided to go to greener pastures and the previous departmental head has retired. We now have a new departmental head and a new Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the change in the leading roles of the departmental head and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) presages a re-examination of the proposal which has been outlined so well and so fluently and the dangers of which were exposed so clearly by the honourable member for Herbert. Indeed, I hope that in some ways the honourable member represents the new voice of the Government in this area, because everything that he said about the Soviet Union, about what it has done and about how it uses fishing fleets, is accurate. That being said, one must ask: How could we enter into a deal with the Soviet Union which would give access to our ports with the kinds of dangers that the honourable member has outlined? If we did enter into such a deal, is it not inevitable that this would be taken by the island states on which we have prevailed to avoid entanglements with the Soviet Union to mean that it was now time for them to reconsider their position?

We cannot expect the island states to believe that there is one foreign policy for Australia towards the Soviet Union and another foreign policy which they must follow because they are not big enough to play in the kind of league that some of us think that we can play in. When I say that some of us think that we can play in a certain kind of league, I refer to those who believe that we can enter into agreements with the Soviet Union in areas touching on our security interests and somehow emerge unscathed. That extraordinary naivety was displayed by the previous Foreign Minister. There are echoes of it in the Prime Minister's approach to the fishing deal, notwithstanding what has been said about his scepticism. If the Prime Minister is sceptical and if, as I say, the views just put by the honourable member for Herbert are accepted by the Government as being sound, as unquestionably they are, the dangerous proposal which is presently under examination should be dropped and the Government should announce its position quickly so that we can get on with the business of dealing with the Soviet Union and forget about having a fishing deal which will involve all of the problems and all of the dangers outlined so well by the honourable member for Herbert.

I now turn to a subject of current interest; that is, our aid program. Aid is the single largest component of spending in the foreign policy area. This Government came to power some years ago on a boast, amongst other things, that it would increase aid. Promises were made and promises were, of course, broken. This Government has developed the breaking of promises into an everyday art form. The present level of aid, when calculated as a proportion of gross national product, is the lowest in 25 years. At present about 0.36 per cent of our gross national product is spent on aid. In the last year of the Fraser Government the figure was much higher: it was around 0.5 per cent. Yet, with all this Government's promises, we are down to 0.36 per cent. Who knows where we will be when the Government faces up to the grim prospect of making savings for the purpose of the foreshadowed tax cuts?

In the administration of aid some rather curious priorities have been demonstrated in recent times. We have seen the recent downgrading of five Pacific island states. Aid to Bangladesh has dropped from around $22m in 1985-86 to around $15.5m in 1987-88. That $15.5m includes $1.5m of recent emergency aid. I remind honourable members that Bangladesh is one of the most dirt-poor countries in the world, with a vast population afflicted by recent national disasters of a magnitude that it is impossible for us even to contemplate, with the result that millions are homeless. Yet our response has been to increase aid to Bangladesh by $1.5m at the same time as we have increased aid to Fiji by $10m.

Senator Evans visited Fiji recently. He went there, among other reasons, for the purpose of finding out what is going on. We know what is going on in Fiji. It was unwise of Senator Evans to go back to Fiji so quickly after being snubbed so directly by the Fijian Government, as he was when he wanted to see Dr Bavadra, whom I met when I visited Fiji in late 1987, as I met General Rabuka and members of the then Fijian interim military government. What does the Government say? I quote from the Budget Papers. In terms of Australia's overseas aid program, the Government says:

Firm assurances have been received from the Government of Fiji that Australian Government aid equipment and materials will not be diverted from intended developmental purposes and in particular will not be applied in any way to assist or support military activities.
In relation to the additional $10m it says:

In the implementation of this program the Australian Government will take account of political, constitutional, economic and social developments in Fiji, including human rights, as well as Fiji Government priorities.

We know something about the track record of the Fijian Government in human rights and we have known more since the publication of the draft Constitution for the Republic of Fiji in September this year. Let me remind the Committee what that draft Constitution does. Effectively, it entrenches Fiji racial dominance in the political system. Of the 71 members of parliament, 22 are to be Indians-I think the Indians presently make up 48 per cent of the population of Fiji-eight are to be on the general list and there is to be one rota man representative, 28 are to be elected Fijians and 12 are to be nominated: eight by the President and four by the Prime Minister. One does not need to be an expert in mathematics to understand what the result will be.

Looking at the Constitution itself one sees that, either explicitly or effectively, the result of the Constitution will be as follows: The President will be a Fijian; the Prime Minister will be a Fijian; the Commander of the Armed Forces will be a Fijian; most interestingly, the Commander of the Police will be a Fijian; and the Chairman of the Public Service Commission will be a Fijian-that board has the power to make appointments to public office-as will be the Chairman of the Police Service Commission, who has power to make senior appointments to the police force.

The draft Constitution is an elegant document at first blush. It has in it a statement of rights which, if one does not look beyond the index, looks to be good. If one looks further one sees that all the so-called fundamental rights and freedoms are qualified out of existence. For example, one's right to personal liberty is there, but one may be confined in specified areas. One may be subject to public emergency decrees. There is one there now, administered by the Minister of Home Affairs and Commander of the Fijian Armed Forces and coup leader, General-as he is now-Rabuka.

The Government must ask itself this very serious question: How can it possibly, at this stage, accept the assurances that have been given to it? What is the possible justification for increasing aid to Fiji out of a very limited aid budget when the Fijian Government is obviously determined to entrench race as the basis of political power and has treated this Government and its Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade in a way which could only be described as contemptuous? What are our priorities and what are our principles? Are there not other countries in far greater need of the extra aid that we would provide to Fiji? The Foreign Minister will no doubt be making his recommendations to his Government. I hope that when he does so he looks very carefully at the Constitution so that he can understand the magnitude of the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to direct my comments to the South Pacific which is, in a general sense, the most important foreign relations policy area that this country has. I was interested to hear the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), make the comments he did about Fiji. For quite some time the Opposition has jumped from foot to foot in regard to its policies on Fiji. I was interested in what the honourable member had to say. I will speak about Fiji a little later in my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Initially, I want to raise the general question of aid in relation to Australia and the South Pacific. What do we mean by aid? I suppose aid has many branches to it. We can talk about budget aid which we give to Papua New Guinea. I believe that this type of aid always has to be treated with care. We can talk about basic food and medical aid, which has a proper place. But, unquestionably in my mind, the main element of aid should be of a development kind-economic development, infrastructure development and, probably more importantly, particularly in some of the smaller states, human resources development.

Pacific island people to whom I speak-and I am sure that this applies to people in other parts of the world-often say, `Sure, the aid that we have been given is wonderful. It has helped us. But, really, we cannot get the fullest benefit out of it because we just do not have the people within our country to continue the programs that have been started'. This is a complex issue because the problems change from country to country. Every country has its particular problem. I suppose in this context I can talk about education. Recently, I led a delegation from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade throughout the South Pacific. We visited eight countries. They were in order the Solomon Islands, Tonga, Fiji, Western Samoa, Tuvalu, Kiribati, Nauru and Vanuatu. We met a wide cross-section of the community, including business people, individuals from the societies concerned and government people. (Quorum formed)

Of course, the quorum was called because the Opposition Whip is trying to deflect attention from the Opposition's lack of policies; because it got done like a dinner at Question Time; because it has a leadership problem which it cannot hide and which will not go away. He will be doing exactly what he is doing now for many years to come. Luckily, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) will be at home, having retired on his well-earned pension. The honourable member for Indi (Mr Ewen Cameron) will still be sitting on the other side of the chamber. It will be a very long time before he gets over here.

I would like to return to the departmental estimates which are before the Committee. The delegation from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade had a marvellous trip throughout the Pacific. We met the Prime Minister of the Solomon Islands and the Crown Prince of Tonga. The honourable member for North Sydney said that he met several people in Fiji. The Committee had a personal audience with Brigadier Rabuka and the Prime Minister. In fact, we had a 2 1/2-hour meeting with the full Cabinet. Beyond that, we met every other President and Prime Minister, concluding with a meeting with Prime Minister Lini in Vanuatu. It was a very successful trip. Everywhere we went in the Pacific people came to us and talked about education and health. People in every country talked about the varying problems that they had. It was quite obvious that education and health were two of the major concerns of every country in the South Pacific.

Education is part of the human resources problem. There is a need to try to educate people for the tasks that countries need to undertake either in the home country, in the region or here in Australia. Some countries were upset and did not believe that the University of the South Pacific was doing the job it should be doing. That claim is open to debate because I think it has done a fairly good job. But some of the South Pacific states do not feel that the university is appropriate to the needs of their countries any more. Indeed, I understand that Western Samoa has set up an arm of the university and that one of the subjects is Western Samoan culture, which is probably one of the strongest cultures and traditions of the South Pacific.

As I said, problems were raised in regard to education and health. Of course, we must deal with the fundamental problems that most South Pacific countries face in terms of communications, transport and infrastructure support. Obviously I cannot deal with those problems at any length today. Suffice it to say, the level of our aid to the Pacific has gone up. Suffice it to say that page 11 of Budget Related Paper No. 4 for 1988-89, regarding our aid program, shows that country programs to the South Pacific in total amounted to $49.7m in 1984-85, and the estimate for 1988-89 has risen to $84.9m-or a 70 per cent increase in four years. It shows the Government's commitment to the South Pacific. There is a lot to be done. I believe economic growth, infrastructure support and human resources development must be fully sorted out and supported by this country. I think many more debates on this subject should occur in this House, and I hope I will have the opportunity to say more on this very important subject at another time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not plan to speak, but I noticed that a certain member was listed to say a few words on these estimates and as he is not here I will take this opportunity. I do so because I am very concerned about the importance of trade and our trade performance and the need to ensure that every action that could be taken is taken to ensure that our export industries, whether they be the farming industry, the mining industry or the manufacturing industry, are given every encouragement that the country can afford to alleviate our balance of trade problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Hawke Government has been in office there has been a lot of selective cutting of government expenditure. The three areas that have suffered most are, sadly, the primary industry, trade and transport infrastructure areas. There has been an enormous shift in resources. I am in the process of putting together a table to indicate what has happened in this country in the past 25 years. I do not blame this Government entirely. I blame the trend of public opinion that has occurred over that period. I am sick and tired of hearing people condemning Sir John McEwen and blaming him and the Menzies-McEwen Government for the problems we are suffering today. I think it is wrong to do that.

The fact is that there has been a very substantial drop in investment in manufacturing industry in this country. A committee report was tabled in this Parliament which showed that since the mid-1960s there has been an alarming drop in investment in manufacturing. It has picked up recently, but in terms of the gross domestic product (GDP) it has not picked up to any great extent. I hope these tables will give some graphic illustration of what is going on in Australia. Over the past 25 years we have seen a reduction in the export percentage of GDP and a reduction in the investment percentage of GDP, and the transfer of resources, in a budgetary sense, from the productive sector of the Australian community to other sectors has been occurring alarmingly.

There is no wonder that we are facing a balance of trade problem. We are relying on our basic industries, on our agricultural and mining industries, much more than perhaps we should in order to earn foreign exchange. I do not believe in the so-called level playing field concept. It has become the in thing, the sort of thing that people have latched themselves onto as a philosophy. The market forces theory that has now permeated the policies of, I think, both the Opposition and the Government is really based on the view that market forces in themselves will determine the making of the right decisions so far as investment and the economy are concerned. I do not believe that, because it is the factors that affect the market forces on the international market that will determine the actual market structure.

I know that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy), has been doing a tremendous job as the Minister responsible for trade in keeping together the Cairns Group, in trying to ensure that we have a more rational international trading environment for agriculture. I wish him well, and I hope that the Cairns Group is successful in showing some progress at the Montreal mid-term review in December. I know that the Minister has done everything in his power to ensure that progress is made. But I wonder whether at the end of the Uruguay Round we are going to see countries such as the United States of America and Canada, and all the countries in the European Community, adopt the policy that we have adopted-the level playing field concept. I wonder whether they are going to remove the subsidies applying to agriculture or whether they are going to create the sort of fair trading environment that we would like to see. In setting an example to the rest of the world, we have to be very careful that we do not find ourselves as one of the few exporting countries that have adopted a purist approach to trade. If other countries do not follow our noble example, we could well find ourselves in an even worse situation with our balance of trade than we are presently in.

I think that John McEwen had the right idea to a large extent. When he was the Trade Minister for this country he established the fact that Australia was the twelfth greatest trading nation on earth. It is now twenty-third, behind Singapore and Hong Kong. He pursued a policy of encouraging, by various means, investment in various industries. Sure, he did not attack the tariff problem as soon as he should have, but he did recognise that there is no such thing as a level playing field in the world. I hope that Australia and this Government do not assume that we are going to achieve the so-called level playing field, the fair market that we would like to see, because I cannot see countries such as those in Europe, and the United States, in my lifetime reducing to any extent the subsidies that are available, for instance, to their farming sectors.

Australia is facing a very serious standard of living problem. I do not think there is any more important field of endeavour for the Government than to concentrate on improving our export performance, whether it be in the primary industry area, in the mining area, or in the manufacturing area; or in the high technology area, which has a long way to go. I feel it was a great mistake to amalgamate trade with foreign affairs. I think trade is so important to this nation that it should be a separate portfolio. I think we should be giving it more emphasis and priority than this Government is giving it. I hope that when there is a change of government, the government of the day will see the necessity of re-establishing the old trade department and giving it the sort of support that I believe is necessary to improve the living standards of Australians. The standard of living of Australians is so heavily dependent upon trade and exports that we have a tremendous responsibility and opportunity in the next 10 or so years to establish ourselves as one of the great exporting nations in this area of the world, where half the world's population is living. We have a great challenge in front of us. Unless we grapple with this problem and unless we give this area sufficient resources, I forecast that we will continue down that dreadful Argentinean track that so many people talk about.

We must look at the tax system and remove those taxes, for instance from fuel, that are making it difficult for exporting industries to compete. To increase excise on fuel from 6c a litre to 21c a litre and to tax fuel to the extent that we are taxing it, is certainly making it even more difficult for our industries to compete on that world market. Any tax that discriminates against the export sector should be reviewed and removed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few comments on our aid program, in particular that within our region. I also want to make some comments in response to the remarks made by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), for whom I have very high regard. When this Government assumed office, Australia's industrial situation was very parlous indeed. In fact, when we assumed office in 1983-84, capital expenditure was $13,021m; at present it is $23,262m. That is an increase on what was actually a decline of 12.6 per cent when we assumed office in 1983-84. That has now been increased to a 5.8 per cent increase. In other words, it is a pretty rapid turnaround. That has not occurred without a government policy which has brought to the attention of manufacturing industry the need to be export oriented. It is terribly important.

SPEECH.PARA: There are certain terms which have been used today which probably reflect the Government's policies. TALK.START.PARA: —During the 1980s there has been a terrible depression in developing countries. Living standards in many parts of Southern Asia, Sub-Sahara Africa and Latin America have fallen by around 15 per cent. This means that average living standards of already impoverished people have fallen even further. The World Bank estimates that there are now nearly a billion people living in absolute poverty. Absolute poverty is described by the Bank as `a condition of life so degraded by disease, illiteracy, malnutrition and squalor as to deny its victims basic human necessities'. At least another billion have such poor living standards that they are barely adequate for even a minimally secure and satisfactory life. So it is essential for all humane and reasonable people to contribute in whatever way is possible to reduction of this terrible misery. That is the central goal of the Australian aid program.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia gives about $1,100m a year in a well-structured, high quality aid program to developing countries, partly in bilateral aid to our near neighbours, partly through multilateral agencies and a small proportion through non-government organisations. It is very good to see the high level of public support for Australian aid programs. It is a clear indication that the great majority of Australians want to make a contribution to ending the terrible impoverishment which I have described. However, there is not nearly enough knowledge around the community about the ways in which our aid funds are actually used.

To illustrate, I would like briefly to describe one excellent aid project in Indonesia which I visited a couple of weeks ago. This project, the Bah Bolon project, is in North Sumatra and involves flood control, irrigation and rural extension. The project includes building levees along three distributory rivers in a delta so as to contain any flood, up to the most serious flood, which is likely to occur in any 10-year period. The channelled water is then used for irrigating rice and vegetable production. The project also involves training farmers in the use of improved, high yielding rice and vegetables.

The Indonesian Government has a goal of maintaining self-sufficiency in rice production; yet this potentially fertile land in the Bah Bolon river delta was in the past subject to almost annual flooding which greatly reduced its productivity. The effect of the project will be to stop flooding in most years so that rice production will be able to continue uninterrupted. This will greatly increase the productivity of the land, increasing rice yields and enabling a substantial increase of several thousand hectares in the area of land which can be cropped. The project began in 1983 and is expected to continue for two or three years more. Australia is providing 60 per cent of the funds and the Indonesian Government 40 per cent. Australia's contribution totals $32m. The project team involves a dozen Australians and about 150 Indonesians.

When visiting the project last week I was impressed by the technical complexity of the task. Not only is building the levees a major engineering task, but also experts in agricultural science, fisheries, the environment and social development have been employed. The project is popular with the local people because it will substantially increase their incomes and prevent the regular disruption of their lives caused by flooding. Not surprisingly there have been significant technical problems in the building of the levees and the weirs, but each of those is being resolved as it is met. This project is one example of the excellent work being done through the Australian aid program. This project will lead to a substantial improvement in agricultural productivity and living standards in a relatively poor area of north Sumatra.

I congratulate all the project personnel and the aid administrators who conceived and planned the project and wish them success as they tender for three additional projects of this type which the Indonesian Government is now planning. Mr Deputy Chairman, I am a member of a panel which is judging aid projects to give awards for excellence, and have been tremendously impressed--(Quorum formed)

This amounts to suppression of discussion about the problem of global poverty. I am very disappointed that the Opposition would involve itself in this kind of silly diversionary tactic. I was saying before being so inappropriately interrupted that I am a member of a panel which is judging aid projects to give awards for excellence, and have been tremendously impressed by the appropriateness and the value of the projects. Every one of 40 or so projects, about which I read carefully, was worth doing and has been realised efficiently and imaginatively-in ways appropriate to the situations of recipient countries. Australians can be proud of the quality of our aid program. These examples illustrate the value of the whole program.

Increasing aid would be a most important step towards a greater contribution to sustainable development in developing countries. In the 1988 Budget, the decline in Australia's overseas development assistance (ODA) was arrested. Aid was kept at 0.36 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) so that there was a modest but real increase in aid of about $10m. At present Australia provides almost $1,100m in overseas aid. This might sound a lot but it is far below the level provided by other Western countries. The present Western average, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development development assistance committee unweighted average of the proportion of aid to gross national product (GNP), was 0.49 per cent in 1987, compared with our own 0.36 per cent. In 1987, Norway gave over one per cent of its GNP, the Netherlands nearly one per cent and Sweden 0.85 per cent. Japan has rapidly increased its ODA from $3.4 billion in 1980 to over $10 billion this year, and Italy is doing the same.

Increased aid is justified not only by humanitarian concern for the impoverished and a general commitment to fairness, but also by our economic and strategic interests. Australia is the largest northern country in the Southern Hemisphere. As a commodity exporter we experience the same destructive impact of Northern Hemisphere policies as does the rest of the south. More directly, our export and investment opportunities increase with the growth of developing country markets in Asia.

It has to be said that the Government's action in merging those two departments reflects the very high priority that we accord to addressing Australia's external economic problems. Despite the fact that honourable members opposite keep saying that not enough has been done in the bilateral area, there have been considerable achievements in this area. In regard to major markets such as Japan, the Government has obtained important assurances to the effect that trade disputes with third countries will not be resolved at Australia's expense. I remind those opposite of the beef agreement negotiated with Japan only a matter of a couple of months ago. That is probably the most significant trade agreement negotiated in the history of this country. It is a little different from the one that the National Party came back with years ago, which was positively discriminatory against this country. It positively discriminated against Australia in favour of the United States. When we talk about bilateral agreements, we should not forget that the one the National Party negotiated was a little ripper. From our point of view it was discriminatory, and we have fixed that.

In regard to China, we have been able to take advantage of a rapidly growing market. That is not a bad effort on the bilateral side. In the case of the United States, some of the worst aspects of the omnibus trade legislation have been modified or deleted. Admittedly, the legislation is still basically protectionist but, in so far as it specifically affected Australia, its worst measures have been modified or deleted largely as a result of our bilateral efforts-not only government but industry representations. We have had a comprehensive review of the relationship with our third largest market, New Zealand, under the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations trade agreement. That agreement now contains what could not have been imagined as possible under the previous Government to accelerate free trade between the two countries and includes the most comprehensive agreement on trade and services that has been negotiated by any two countries. It is more extensive than the agreement that has been negotiated between the United States and Canada. I thought that I should just mention those matters in relation to issues raised by the right honourable member for New England. He continues to say such things because, I think, in his view a good story ought not to be confused by facts. But, if we keep putting them forward often enough, the message may get through.

The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) spent some time on the question of aid. In tough economic times it is not as easy as some people, particularly those in opposition, would make out to have as much money in some areas as we would all like. But it has to be said that the aid allocation of this Government has enabled spending to be maintained in real terms on ongoing programs for major recipients in South East Asia and the Pacific while allowing for some growth in other country programs. We have acknowledged our special responsibility towards our immediate neighbours, particularly Papua New Guinea and South Pacific countries. Reference was made to this matter by the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) when he pointed out the increase in aid from just under $50m to about $84m. He dealt with that matter in some detail, and I will not go over it again.

The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) raised an issue which was of particular concern to him, as no doubt it was to the honourable member for North Sydney. In regard to poverty and the aid program, the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau has recently embarked on a study of ways to incorporate a greater focus on poverty in the aid program. The study aims to review how the aid program contributes to poverty alleviation at present and to suggest ways of increasing the poverty focus of the program.

The main reasons for the study are the persistence of poverty in developing countries, as indicated by the member for Fraser-in fact, the worsening of that position-the need to eradicate poverty in any real process of development; the increased attention being paid to poverty alleviation by both international and national development organisations; and concerns in the Australian community, particularly among non-government organisations, that the aid program does not do enough to alleviate poverty. That study was announced at the world development debate in Canberra on 27 August of this year. The Australian Council for Overseas Aid has expressed an interest in the study and an outline of the study has been provided to the Council for information and comment. I acknowledge what has been said about those matters but the issues are being addressed.

The honourable member for Gwydir is a person who is held in great respect by both sides of the House, and I thank him for his acknowledgment of the amount of work that has been done at a multilateral level. But I do not propose to deal with what he was on about today because his talk about the drop off in the manufacturing industry in this country until recent times was more than adequately answered by the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren). Although the honourable member for Gwydir may not like criticism of the Menzies- McEwen era in relation to that matter, the fact is that the matters outlined by the honourable member for Ballarat are correct. There was a period in this country when the manufacturing industry was going down. It was not facing the cool wind of change. It thought it could go on in a protected way for ever and was not facing up to the need for international competitiveness. As the member for Ballarat pointed out, one of the major issues which faced this Government when it came to office was the need to restructure our manufacturing industry. We have done that in a way that has not been achieved by any other government. The criticism of that period, presided over by the late Mr Menzies and Mr McEwen, is very justified. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity of this Estimates debate to examine a very interesting decision-I think it is a landmark decision-in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, entitled `Castle Bacon'. One of the central points of disagreement in the debate on industrial relations is the role to be played by employers and employees on a direct negotiation basis. Basically, the Government's position is that, unless there is a union to negotiate and to fix deals within the confines of a total package which has been dictated to the Government by the trade union movement, all hell will break loose and confusion and chaos will reign in the economy. It loads us up with all sorts of statistics to prove that thanks to the accord all great goodness and economic benefit have descended upon the land. Of course, that is a load of absolute nonsense. As time goes on and as I have the opportunity, as the new shadow Minister for Industrial Relations, I will make it absolutely clear that the facts do not substantiate the Government's position.

SPEECH.PARA: The Castle Bacon Pty Ltd case was very interesting because in pursuance of the productivity tier, the 4 per cent, the union delegate and the employer in Castlemaine, which is a provincial city 120 kilometres from Melbourne, sat down and came to some sensible arrangements about how they should operate that particular enterprise. The union delegate put forward and negotiated various set-offs and he and the employer came to some different arrangements about the starting and finishing times for the business. That was primarily aimed at having a continuous production arrangement. It was all common sense. They came to some arrangements about show day or cup day, whatever it was, and made arrangements to pay people by cheque or by direct deposit into their accounts.

That was all fine. Castle Bacon is one of the major employers in Castlemaine. The employees, through their union delegate, and the employer sat down and said, `Look, we have a stake in the future of this business'. The employees were asked what changes in work practices in return for a 4 per cent wage increase they were prepared to make for the benefit of the company. So they came to a deal. Some weeks after this arrangement had been entered into, the union's assistant secretary waltzed into Castlemaine and said, `Look, if the deal is not in accordance with the deal we have done with Don Smallgoods, I am afraid we will not have a bar of it'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it another Mudginberri?

—It is an interesting follow-up to Mudginberri and I think it will go down as a precedent of very great significance, as was the case with Mudginberri. Of course, the matter ended up in the Arbitration Commission and the first person to hear it in the Commission said, `Look, unless the union has been in on the deal right from the word go, then you cannot have this arrangement put into place'. The Commission awarded the 4 per cent. The people got the wage increase but there were basically no set-offs to match it.

SPEECH.PARA: There were 520 employees at Castle Bacon and 460 of those had actually signed a voluntary agreement to say what they were prepared to do and what changes they were prepared to accommodate to improve the efficiency of Castle Bacon in which they all had a future stake. After that first decision which just said, `You cannot have this arrangement', the company took the matter to the Full Bench and got a very good decision on 5 October 1988. Basically, the Full Bench said, `We are greatly influenced by the fact that the employees by voluntary agreements have entered into an acceptance of the proposals worked out between the union delegate and the employer'.

The Commission did not simply endorse the voluntary agreement; it arbitrated and produced an award variation specific to Castle Bacon which reflected the voluntary agreement. So, in essence, it gave official sanction to the substance of the agreement. That is very important because what we say is wrong with industrial relations in this country is that not enough attention is given to the capacity of employees and employers to sit down and work out agreements which are in the interests of both parties.

In Victoria the meatworkers union has basically been a disaster for that industry. There is only basically Don Smallgoods Co. Pty Ltd and Castle Bacon Pty Ltd left of the big operators. The Mayfair company went to Queensland. In regard to the dispute at Mayfair, the union said that it was a great success whereby the union won over the employer and defeated the company. Five hundred jobs were lost in Bendigo and the union says that is a success! The Dandy company no longer produces in Victoria because of industrial disputes and the Hutton company is now producing out of Victoria. The union was not interested in the affairs of the union members. It was more interested in getting stuck into the bosses. The good thing about Castle Bacon is that it gives an opening to employers and employees who want to sit down and work out sensible arrangements to improve the productivity of the companies in which they have a stake in the future.

The Government has been saying that this is not bad because it shows that under a centralised system we can have the benefits of voluntary agreements. I am sorry the Minister is not here because I had hoped that in finishing off these estimates he would give us a more formal statement on the Government's attitude to Castle Bacon, but I think honourable members have a pretty good idea of the Government's view, because in the industrial relations package which has been going through the Parliament and which has been completed today, in the Senate the Opposition parties put up a whole series of amendments to facilitate employers and employees doing exactly what they did at Castle Bacon. What did the Government do? It voted against them. On each and every occasion that amendments were put up by us to encourage this attitude of cooperation between employers and employees, the Government said no, because it does not suit its idea of industrial relations in this country being by and large controlled by a trade union movement.

The Government likes to carp and criticise the Opposition's industrial relations policy, and its strongest attack in terms of constancy of its repetition is to say that we are confrontationist. The truth of the matter is exactly the opposite. The basis of our industrial relations policy is to encourage employers and employees to get together to make arrangements to improve the productivity of their workplace. That is the basis of our industrial relations policy. It is very simple and it is very straightforward. It is based on commonsense. If we want to see real reform in this country and a real increase in people's living standards, there is only one way forward, and that is at the corporate level, at the enterprise level, to encourage a new spirit of cooperation between employers and employees. It is about time the Government realised the gap between its rhetoric and its real policy position. It is about time it adopted more of the amendments that we have put.

Large companies, whether Australian based or internationally based, are mostly multinational in fiscal policy. These companies can even threaten to move their entire operations offshore, and often do so. Unfortunately, despite the apparent high returns by such companies, a careful review of balance sheets often shows that profits have arisen through asset trading which may make the shareholder happy but adds absolutely nought to the industrial strength and capability of our country. In fact the current experience in Western countries is that industrial growth does not arise from large companies. Large companies in general are conservative and acquisitive. In contradistinction to Japanese industry, Australian industry, particularly large companies, seek early high rates of return on investment. This results in a low level of speculative investment and hence negligible chance of investment in new and rapidly growing industrial opportunities.

At the other end of the scale we have a plethora of small companies-those with a turnover of under $10m-with little opportunity or capability to grow rapidly through export. It is important that governments both Federal and State continually review the effects of policy on small business and endeavour to create special conditions to provide small business with the activation energy necessary to leap into a scale of operations conducive to export growth. It is the $10m to $100m corporations that I believe are the necessary basis for the next phase of Australia's industrial redevelopment. I will be working actively during the period of this Government to develop policies for this level of industry, policies which facilitate investment for enabling new technologies, provide incentives for establishment of new manufacturing industries, reward corporations for research and development which attains export business, and reward industry which returns its profits to the Australian people whether by reinvestments, dividends, or other services.

People talk of governments risking taxpayers' money. What is so new about governments wasting taxpayers' money? Governments of any complexion always waste taxpayers' money. I suggest to honourable members opposite that it is better to use the money in an honest endeavour to create wealth, to create employment, and to push forward the fortunes of our nation than to squander the money in other ways, for instance, in unemployment benefits generated by the government's lack of vision. Fortunately for the public in Western Australia, the Government changed and, to some extent, the present Western Australian Government has been able to redeem the situation somewhat. I believe that the Government, rather than receiving brickbats for this, should be highly commended for what it has done. In the brief time left to me I want to talk about some of the other industry developments that we have seen. TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) had much to say about the recent decision of the Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in respect of Castle Bacon Pty Ltd. The Opposition generally sought to make much of that decision. In effect it heralds it as the epitome of what the Opposition's industrial relations policies are all about. But by some contorted argument, the shadow spokesman for industrial relations, the honourable member for Flinders, then asserted that this example typified what is wrong with industrial relations in Australia and that the Opposition's proposed amendments to the recently passed Industrial Relations Bill were supported by reference to the Castle Bacon case-a case which the Opposition presented as some kind of Mudginberri mark 2.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the Committee's attention to the facts of the case and, in particular, what it tells us about the current system of industrial relations and wage fixation in this country as it has operated under the current Government's policies. The Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission recently upheld an appeal by Castle Bacon against a decision of a single member of the Commission. The key issue before the Commission was the application of the restructuring and efficiency principle. The Full Bench considered submissions from all parties including evidence from the employer regarding agreements reached with a majority of its employees. The Bench proceeded to arbitrate substantially in favour of the employer determining that, on the merits, the employer's proposals were within the scope and intentions of the restructuring and efficiency principle of the two-tier wage system.

The Opposition has attempted to characterise the outcome of the Castle Bacon case as something other than the due process of the Commission exercising its powers under the current system. It sought to present it as some kind of victory; that the Commission was upholding an agreement reached between the employees of Castle Bacon and Castle Bacon itself. That was not the case. What happened was that the Commission, within the scope and intentions of the restructuring and efficiency principle of the two-tier wage system, upheld a variation of the award appealed against in relation to a decision by a single commissioner. The Opposition fails to acknowledge-and I think to understand-that a decision was reached under the system without any recourse to the opting out procedure or the like, just as the Mudginberri decision was the outcome of due processes of the Commission. It clearly gives the lie therefore to characterisations of our current institutional arrangements as highly rigid and inflexible which is the key note of the Opposition's rhetoric on this subject.

The Castle Bacon decision, far from supporting the case for a swag of amendments that were moved in the other place to the recently passed Industrial Relations Bill, demonstrates the false basis upon which those amendments were cast. The honourable member for Flinders, in his press release of 10 October, got it all wrong; the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), in his press release of the same day, got it all wrong; and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, in his statement reported in the West Australian of 13 October this year, got it all wrong. As I say, the Castle Bacon decision, far from supporting the case for the swag of amendments to the Government's Industrial Relations Bill, demonstrated the false basis upon which those amendments were cast. In short, the current system is flexible and is contributing importantly to more cooperative relationships between employers, employees and their unions which in turn is assisting in boosting Australia's efficiency and productivity performance.

Of course, the Government's wages and industrial relations policies have been key elements underpinning a dramatic shift in the industrial relations culture and wage fixing arrangements. The Government's approach is based upon consultation and cooperation. It is demonstrably bringing home the bacon in terms of jobs, profits, investment, international competitiveness and industrial harmony. The Government's approach is to be contrasted with the Opposition's rag bag of ideas aimed at undermining the current institutional arrangements, aimed at generating confrontation by an unwarranted attack on a responsible trade union, and aimed at advocating a wholesale free for all or open slather approach to wage negotiations which would be both economically irresponsible and industrially disastrous.

I conclude with the words I used earlier today: the member for Flinders represents the mouth of divisiveness, confrontation and fragmentation. The Opposition's industrial relations policy means destruction of the progress and stability that Australian industry has enjoyed under this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Since our election in 1983 it has been essential to induce industry to contribute directly to research and development, and this is happening, although at a far slower rate than we had hoped.
