Under the Fraser Government, and to some extent under our Government as well, the prevailing philosophy was to see the role of government as to compensate for market failure. If the market did not contribute enough to research, there was an obligation on government to top it up. I think we are now recognising that the international trading situation, the development of new products and services which are sweeping the world market and which are contributing to our unfavourable balance of trade, has moved far faster than most people anticipated.

As a result, there was the announcement last week by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of a very speedy review of science capacity in order to identify key elements to link science and technology policy to government policies already formulated on structural adjustment for industry and on education, to advise on actions that will be taken in 1988-89, this Budget year, to support research in areas of national importance, to advise on actions to increase awareness in industry of the need for collaboration in major, long term projects where large amounts of `patient money' will be required, to advise on initiatives in research that could be implemented in 1989-90--(Quorum formed)

The review committee will also report on initiatives in research that could be implemented in 1989-90 and sustained in later years that would strengthen research, assist appropriate international linkages and contribute to industry and to Australia's national responsibilities and advise on ways to signal the importance of science as a factor in national life in addition to the substantial economic benefits which may accrue. Finally, the committee should draw as necessary on comparative overseas policies and performances in relation to both private and public research and development. The committee will prepare an initial discussion paper for the Structural Adjustment Committee of Cabinet by the end of November. I think we are moving very fast. I am very much encouraged by that.

The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) launched into an attack on the industrial portfolio owned by the South Australian Government, saying that it was `totally inappropriate and crowding out the private sector'. He also criticised Victoria and Western Australia for being involved in business undertakings. He came out with a rallying cry which I thought was almost of the late President Calvin Coolidge, saying that business is the business of business. But the point is that, whatever the particular brand of economic philosophy that is being pursued by the Government in the Commonwealth of Australia, we are essentially pluralist. I do not see us as taking a particular narrow, doctrinal line and saying, `This is the decision we make in Canberra and this has to be imposed on the States'. It is curious for an Opposition which, when it suits it, parrots out the argument in strong defence of States rights, which urged a No vote at the recent referendum because it said it wanted to protect States rights, the right of States to go their own way, to turn around and say that that is quite wrong; that the Commonwealth Government ought not to allow the Government of South Australia to engage in business enterprises because it is inconsistent with the political philosophy expressed in our Budgets, and that the only way in which one can express a commitment to the business sector is to leave that sector entirely to private enterprise.

The private sector has not always been very enterprising. I endorse entirely the words of my colleague the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) when he said that the problem with too much of business has been its commitment towards the bottom line-its preoccupation with getting a cash return in the shortest possible period. There are some times when I think government is absolutely entitled to have a go, to take the long view. To some extent, of course, that has been the procedure adopted through the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC).

In Australia at the moment we are pursuing many developments which we believe will have very important long term effects. I point to the research project on the development of a malaria vaccine as an example of something which there is no indication would be funded if it were left to the market and to the private banking sector. We have to take the long term view. Individual governments and cabinets have made decisions in this area, as we made a decision recently to support the malaria vaccine project.

The governments of South Australia, Western Australia and Victoria have, in their wisdom, involved themselves in equity participation in some companies. No doubt, in the long view, not all of those investments will prove to be correct. There will have been errors of judgment, just as there are errors of judgment in the private sector. However, I applaud the fact that the South Australian Government has seen the importance of maintaining a high technology base in its own State-a State which lacks some of the physical advantages of some of the other States. If it sees an opportunity to ensure that important entities such as Fairey Australasia Pty Ltd or Thorn EMI stay in that State, I will be the last to try to deprive it of the opportunity to form that judgment. I thank honourable members for their contributions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the opportunity to discuss matters relating particularly to tourism and sport. We welcome this opportunity mainly because over the last number of months there have not been many chances in this Parliament to discuss matters relating to such important issues as tourism and sport. One of the reasons why there have not been too many debates on sport and tourism is that we have had a change in Minister and, with that, a change in emphasis. The new Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, is not nearly as interested in the portfolios of sport and tourism as was his predecessor. Senator Richardson is primarily interested in the portfolio of the environment. As a consequence, we have seen a distinct lack of debate in these two very important subject areas.

SPEECH.PARA: We also welcome the opportunity to discuss sport and tourism because in recent days the Federal Opposition has been working very hard to compile the relevant policies on the two areas. Recently in Perth I had the honour of presenting the Liberal and National parties' policy on tourism at the Australian Tourist Industry Association's annual conference. Might I say that the new policy was very well received. It was well received because in that policy document we demonstrated a very serious commitment to tourism throughout this country. We have a commitment because on this side of the chamber we realise the tremendous potential that tourism offers the Australian economy and the potential it offers many young Australians for a career path in a very lucrative industry.

At the end of this week in Sydney the Opposition, once again represented by me as the shadow Minister, will be launching its policy on sport. This is something of which I am particularly proud because the Liberal and National parties' new policy on sport gives 110 per cent commitment to this very exciting facet of Australian life. I look forward very much to presenting that policy in Sydney at the end of this week.

It has been very sad in the last couple of months to witness the results of the Federal Budget. The sport budget was cut by 8.3 per cent in the Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in August. The sporting community has recognised this cutback and is most upset. In fact, if we go back over the history of sports funding under this Government we note that, with the exception of the first year or two, sports funding has gradually deteriorated to the point where it now puts in question the viability of a number of functions that the Federal Government has sponsored in years gone by. Indeed, at the end of the day it must have an effect on the performance and ability of Australian sports men and women as they compete not just within Australia but throughout the world.

We saw our Australian sports men and women competing in the last few weeks at the Olympic Games held in Seoul. On behalf not just of members on our side of the House but of all members of this Parliament I extend congratulations to all of those people who wore the green and gold representing Australia in Seoul. We congratulate those who won medals and those who proved to be great ambassadors for Australia. I think that we can walk away very proud and pleased with the results that were achieved over the fortnight or so in which the Seoul Olympic Games took place.

One of the unfortunate aspects of the Seoul games was the highlighting of the use of drugs in sport. As a result of that there is an urgent need for a properly internationally accredited drug testing facility in location and operating here in Australia. A few years ago we had such a facility in Brisbane but, unfortunately, due to some technicalities it lost its international accreditation and, as a consequence, we do not have a proper, internationally accredited drug testing facility in this country. If Australia and this Government wish to be in the forefront in fighting the use of drugs in sport it is imperative that we have one of these facilities in Australia. I think it is important also that the new Minister, Senator Richardson, make a clear and unequivocal commitment to giving whatever support is necessary to ensure that the facility that is mooted to be installed in Sydney for this purpose can be got up and running very quickly indeed.

On both sides of the chamber there is an abhorrence of the use of drugs in sport. The reason for that is that we recognise that the use of drugs for the purpose of enhancing sporting performance is straight-out cheating. There is no other way to describe it. The Opposition policy which will be released, as I mentioned earlier, on Friday this week in Sydney takes a very strong stand against the use of drugs in sport. One of the unfortunate aspects of the change of Ministry has been the fact that the new Minister has not come out with a very strong statement of condemnation of the use of drugs in sport. We look forward to his doing that over the next few months.

There are a number of reasons why drugs should not be used in sport. Not least, of course, is the long term effect they have on the health of those who use them. They also destroy the entire ethos of sport. What we saw happen to Ben Johnson will in the long term prove to be of great benefit to the sporting community because it shows us that no matter how good people are, how important they are or where they are, if at one stage or another in their sporting careers they have used drugs they will be caught out and shame and disgrace will be heaped upon them.

For that reason I believe it is important that this Government should obtain a statement on the attitude of the Australian Medical Association (AMA) towards doctors prescribing anabolic steroids for the purpose of improving sporting performance. Consequently, I hope the AMA will make it against the ethnics of the profession so that if a doctor is found guilty of such an offence, that doctor will be struck off. That is an important initiative that this Government can take up. We look forward to the early return of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). One of the first things on his list of things to do will be to get that unequivocal statement from the Australian Medical Association.

As I mentioned earlier, there is an urgent need for more funding of sport in this country. As I said, the Federal Government in its last Budget, following its practice over the last few years, has actually cut back sport funding by 8.3 per cent. So often we hear from the other side of the House comparisons between this Government's spending and that of other countries. A few moments ago the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) was in here comparing the Federal Government's spending on science and technology with that of Sweden and Switzerland. Let me just make a comparison with other countries in relation to their relevant federal governments' expenditure on sport. Switzerland spends $13.84c per head of population on sport. The USA spends only $7.43. Canada spends $3.12c per head of population on sport. Yet here in Australia, with its miserable lot of bean counters, only $2 a head is spent on sport by the Federal Government. So there is a clear example of why we need to see a greater commitment from this Government to spending more money on sport.

In addition, we not only need to have a commitment from the Government in relation to funding for sport but also need it to give encouragement and incentive to the private sector to invest in more sponsorship of sport. One of the things that have happened over recent times is that within the sporting community these days there is a distinct feeling that sponsorship from the private sector for sport has actually started to wind down. We need to see this Government take the lead by ensuring that there is some incentive, some encouragement, for sport funding from the private sector.

Overall, there is a number of very important matters that need debating but time does not permit that to take place tonight in the few minutes that we have in which to speak. I think the performance of the Australian Institute of Sport and, of course now, its amalgamation with the Australian Sports Commission will be debated later on this week when the subject of the amalgamation of those two organisations comes before the House. That will prove to be most interesting but at the end of the day I think the sporting community of Australia will be able to judge this Government's commitment to sport by purely and simply looking through the Budget Papers and considering how much money, time, effort and support this Government is giving to the sporting community. If it does that, it will find that it is deteriorating substantially and that there is a need for a change in the attitude to funding of sport, not only of the Federal Government but also throughout the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my speech on the Budget the other night, I concluded my remarks by saying that, although I thought the Budget was an excellent one and that I was delighted that tourism and its role in the Australian economy is at long last being recognised, I was appalled at the decision by the Government not to proceed with the building of the Museum of Australia. I am as aware as anyone of the economic difficulties the Government is facing. It is not easy in difficult times for the Government to justify the expenditure of around $100m to build a national museum. As with the Parliament House, it will never be the right time to build it. Governments are never congratulated for taking these sorts of initiatives because there will always be a large section of the community which will argue that the Government's priorities are wrong and that if money of that order is available it ought to be spent on hospitals, schools, roads and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Governments have to live with the fact that their greatest deeds may not be recognised until years after they have departed the political arena. I refer, for example, to the Sydney Opera House. I made the point in my speech on the Budget that Australia is undergoing a boom in tourism largely because in the last few years we have woken up to the fact that a country needs more than just natural beauty, fascinating flora and fauna and friendly people. We have significantly improved the quality of our accommodation and made great strides in the presentation and interpretation of our history and culture. I make particular mention of such new institutions as the Stockman's Hall of Fame, the Great Barrier Reef Wonderland, the Sydney Powerhouse Museum and many others. Australia probably leads the world in its improvement in its presentation.

They are only a sample of the new museum, galleries and interpretative facilities that have made Australia a far more interesting tourist destination, not only for overseas visitors, but also for our own population. It is almost impossible to pick out any one of the cultural facilities and assess the impact it has on tourism. One cannot just say that one brings in so many people and that another brings in so many. What we do know is the collective contribution of these facilities. We know the impact they have on our visitors. Just as London, Washington and Paris attract millions of visitors, both domestic and international, because of their fabulous museums, galleries, historical monuments and theatres, so too in the future will Sydney, Canberra and the other major cities and destinations in Australia have those sorts of attractions for visitors. Imagine for a moment what London would be like without the Tate or the Victoria and Albert Museum; Paris without the Louvre; Washington without the Smithsonian museums? People do not flock to Washington to see Congress. They go there because Washington has the most magnificent museums in the world.

Many governments recognised long ago the connection between the professional presentation of art, heritage and culture and the tourist dollar, alongside the intellectual, educational and interpretative values to their own communities. To some extent we in Australia have too, as the previously mentioned projects that have been built during the past 15 years or so indicate.

In Canberra, the nation's capital, in recent years we have gradually added national cultural institutions that are making this city a place worthy of a visit. In 1982 the Australian National Gallery was opened. In October 1983 the National Film and Sound Archives was established and moved to the former building of the old Institute of Anatomy. The National Science Centre has just opened and, of course, earlier this year the new and permanent Parliament House was opened. Canberra is at long last obtaining the national institutions that will make it truly the national capital and a destination for domestic tourists and international tourists.

Why then are we making this retrograde decision not to proceed with the one major national institution Canberra so desperately needs? The obvious explanation is that the cost of around $100m cannot be afforded in these difficult times. I do not accept that explanation. Having been the Minister for 4 1/2 years I am aware of the background of opposition that occurred from officers in the Department of Finance who have never ceased to do everything possible to abort this proposal from the moment of its conception.

We need very briefly to go back to the days of the Whitlam Government when governments were being bombarded with requests for assistance to existing museums and demands that they build a range of new national museums dealing with everything from sport, immigration, Aborigines, aviation, maritime history, children's institutions and many others. As a result of these pressures the Whitlam Government commissioned the Pigott Committee of Inquiry on Museums and National Collections which in its final report, among many other recommendations, suggested that the Federal Government restrict its activities to three national museums-a national maritime museum, a national aviation museum and a museum of Australia. The maritime museum is under construction in Darling Harbour and will open next year. The national aviation museum is in limbo and although it is likely to be located in Victoria it is not known when that will occur. The Museum of Australia, however, had the support of the Fraser Government which selected the excellent site at Yarramundi Reach near Black Mountain. The present Government has progressed to opening an attractive visitors centre and gradually building up the staff and the collection.

When it is eventually built it will provide a unique perspective on Australia's history by having three separate yet interlocking themes-Aboriginal man, European man, and the environment and their impact upon it. None of the other museums in Australia, almost all of which are in the State capitals and are really nineteenth century style collecting institutions, deals in an effective way with Australia as a nation. Although they have some excellent collections and dedicated staff, largely because of the restriction placed on them by their very structure and style, they are incapable of drawing together all the themes I mentioned earlier and presenting them in a comprehensive, educational and entertaining fashion.

I do not have the time to go into the fascinating, even exhilarating, presentation planned for the National Museum. It will be, if it ever proceeds, one of the finest museums in the world. The problem is that we will be lucky to see it in my lifetime while ever the philistines in Finance have their way. When we were first elected, I too became conscious of the pressures to extend our activities in more and more museums. The Film and Sound Archives apart, which incidentally was already a part of the National Library, I adhered to the view of the Pigott report that we should limit our activities to the three museums recommended by that report. However, I found myself up against violent opposition from Finance. After a prolonged battle, it was decided to have a museums review in which all the issues would be covered. All this did was ensure that a decision about the National Museum of Australia was delayed for a further couple of years. The fact is that the people on the review could never reach any basis for agreement. The philosophical gap was too great.

I never objected to the Department of Finance saying, `Look, we do not object to the principle of a national museum; it is just that we cannot afford it now.' I could have lived with that. In fact, aware of the financial difficulties the Government was facing, I suggested that the museum be introduced in three stages: a gallery of Aboriginal Australia to be opened this year-the year of our bicentennial; the next phase between 1988 and the year 2001; concluding, for Federation, in the year 2001.

What happened-and the people of Australia need to know this-is that the officers from Finance were opposed to the concept that the Federal Government had any responsibility for involvement in museums at all. In the best traditions of Ayn Rand, Milton Friedman and the New Right, these philistines argued that museums were not the responsibility of governments. They advocated not only that we should not build a museum but that the national collection should be either sold off to the private sector or given to the States. `Why would anyone want to come to Canberra to look at a national collection anyway?' one cretin asked me. I suppose it is too much to expect some Class 11 clerk to have anything called vision. But if these particular individuals had been making the decisions in Paris or London in the last century, I wonder whether they would be the cities they are today.

These fools-I call them fools, without equivocation-seemed incapable of realising that we were making decisions not about the national capital for the 1980s but about the national capital for the next century and beyond. What concerned me most was not that these people were giving advice about whether taxpayers' money should be spent; that was their prerogative. I was appalled that these people were giving philosophical advice that was clearly at odds with the philosophy of the Australian Labor Party. They were telling Government Ministers what their philosophy should be. They were saying it was not government's role to preserve the nation's heritage. In my view, they were quite out of order. They had no right to go beyond their level of expertise. They usurped the Government's role as a policy-maker.

I am disgusted at the decision of the Government not to proceed for five years on the National Museum of Australia. I accept that there is a case for a phased building but not a shutdown. We are going to waste millions just keeping the present collection in mothballs. I ask the Government to reconsider this decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to enter this discussion, especially after my colleague the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), and I have a great deal of sympathy with what he has said tonight. He may not realise it, but it is almost 10 years to the day since the House of Representatives Select Committee on Tourism report was tabled in this House and the honourable member for Robertson was a most distinguished member of that Committee and much of what he was talking about tonight was the line that he was taking all through that inquiry, and he obviously has proved to be a man of some vision because we have seen in recent years the benefits that all that infrastructure he was talking about has brought to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I was fascinated to hear his description of the Department's attitude towards Canberra. I understand that, as of today, we are very close indeed to receiving the one millionth visitor through the new and permanent Parliament House. That is an amazing situation-that we have had one million people coming through our doors already. If Canberra is such a boring and dreadful place, it seems amazing to me that people would bother to come here and see this place that has been hailed as the greatest waste of money and has received so many other descriptions that defy mentioning tonight.

It is indicative of the attitude of certain sections of the bureaucracy, and that was the theme of my contribution to the Estimates tonight because 10 years down the track we must do some very considered thinking indeed if we are to make sure that the so-called tourism boom that we have on our hands at the moment will continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were right 10 years ago and they were wrong and they fought us then, if you remember, on tourism.

—The honourable member for Robertson is perfectly correct. I will never forget a certain group of gentlemen who came from Treasury and at that stage they were asked what they thought of the contribution of tourism to the Australian economy, and the answer was that they did not know. We suggested that maybe it would be a good idea if they found out, and we received a shrug on that. We asked them what was the potential contribution of tourism. Not only did they not know, but they did not really care. Their attitude was that it was a froth and bubble industry, one of those things that was there and one did not have to worry about it. It is now Australia's fastest growing industry and one of our biggest employers and, in terms of the contribution to the hard currency that we are earning from around the world, it is our second biggest income earner-despite the bureaucracy.

SPEECH.PARA: We are hitting a situation now that if we do not get our act together 10 years down the track, we may blow all of that good that has come to us and to our economy from the tourist dollar. One thing that has always concerned me-and I spent some time out of this House working in one of the State tourist organisations-and it still concerns me, is the lack of identification by many sections of the bureaucracy of what tourism is all about and what contribution can be made by tourism. It is sad that we have got so far down the track but still miss out on that coordination. It exists in the State bureaucracies as well as in the Federal bureaucracies. One of the great points about the Opposition's tourism policy recently released is a recognition of that and a recognition that there must be a coming together of all sections of the industry, in terms of the private sector and in terms of the various government departments.

Ten years ago that was one of the things that were identified. Tourism was identified as being an industry that was fragmented, that had no capacity to come together to be able to put its case. In terms of the private sector, through the Australian Tourist Industry Association we have seen a coming together of the private sector, but still we lack that coordination in some of the government departments. There are many areas that one can cite. One can cite the lack of coordination between the Department of Aviation and the tourism department. I do not think there is much coordination between the Transport Department and the tourism department. There are all sorts of interdepartmental committees set up from time to time and all sorts of consultative bodies that meet from time to time, and I have been to a number of those meetings. They are very pleasant. One sits there for two days and has a nice lunch, talks to one's fellows from other States and makes all sorts of great and powerful resolutions. Then one goes away-and absolutely nothing happens. The arguments we were having about four and five years ago when I was in that scene are still going on today.

It is about time we started to get our act together if we are to benefit from the potential that is still there for Australia. I think it was John Rowe who said the other day that the Australian tourist industry is not in the middle of a boom. We have just caught up. We are up there with the rest of the world. We really have to make every hit a winner. I think he is perfectly correct. I would never debunk the contribution that has been made by Paul Hogan and his advertising campaigns in the United States, but I wonder whether we are concentrating the expenditure of the tourism dollar in the right places.

It is a fact that the real potential for international tourism into Australia at the moment exists from South East Asia. It is a fact that the biggest potential growth market is Korea because it is now lifting the visa requirement. There is a huge market that is ready to flow out of that country into this part of the world. There might be all sorts of diplomatic problems with Taiwan, but it is opening up to the world and the Taiwanese are now tourists. Interestingly enough, despite the fact that we do not have that recognition, despite the fact that we do not have the air routes, the Taiwanese visitors are coming here now. If one goes to the Gold Coast one sees plenty of them. But have we had any great debate about how we are going to handle the situation of the Taiwanese coming here? The whole area of direct air routes with Korea--

TALK.START.PARA: —And Taiwan.

—Taiwan has been under debate for at least eight or nine years. We do not really seem to be much further down the track. We are continually told that the situation is being monitored. It does take time to get these things into place. If a decision were made now to open up those air routes it would take 12 months, 18 months or two years to get into that market. How much concentration is there in the Australian Tourist Commission and the Department to make sure that we have the capacity to tap that particular market? Are we still in a situation where very little is done between departments? That is a real worry.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Australia has come a long way, as the honourable member for Robertson said earlier, in providing that tourism infrastructure. However, there is other planning we have to do. While I do not necessarily want to promote the concept of a strict, hard and fast government dominated and inspired tourism development plan, there must be some sort of plan for Australia. As I say, we have had a lot of development and that infrastructure is serving us pretty well, but there are a lot of people in the industry who will get their fingers burned because of bad investment decisions. There are instances where some very bad advice has been given, often to developers, by private companies. I wonder, in the geographical sense, whether we have really thought very much about where our future development should go. I wonder how much involvement there has been with the geographers of Australia in the planning of resorts and the best use of our heritage and our natural attractions. I suggest that the answer to that is that there has been very little involvement indeed.

I honestly believe that we are facing a most critical time. The decisions that will be made within the next two or three years are certainly going to determine whether Australia has the capacity to catch up and cash in on that tourism boom. As people who have been involved in the government side of the growth of tourism for the last 10 years, we have a very real obligation to make sure that the bureaucracy gets the message that we have the coordination and the capacity to get together private industry and government departments to make it work. We have to make it work. It is the only growth industry that has the capacity to provide jobs for the young people of Australia. We have 400,000 people who are involved in the industry now. The potential for job creation in tourism is really unlimited.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words about tourism before I move on to the subject of the environment, about which I am particularly concerned. Tourism has come from virtually nowhere five years ago to where it is today through the changes that have been brought about by this Government. As has been mentioned, many jobs have been created. However, I do not think we should put all our eggs into one basket. I would not like to see our economy relying on tourism alone. If anything went wrong in the world economy or things got a little tight, I am quite certain that tourists would not come here. However, the tourism industry is most important and I applaud the Government for what it has done for it.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening I wish to speak about some of the pressures on our environment, which are increasing every minute. Every new human being that is born is increasing the pressures on everything in this world. What happens in the rest of the world affects us here in Australia. Our planet's resources are not infinite, they are very limited, and we must all make certain that we do whatever we can to protect our environment. The classic battle between the environmentalists and the mining industry is an area which concerns me. It has been going on for many years and it will continue. I believe that mining and the protection of the environment can be compatible. We just have not reached that stage yet and I do not think the necessary technology has arrived yet. I can foresee that in the future even national parks will be mined. They will be mined by some sort of robot that digs under the ground and extracts the ore selectively without creating any waste. If something goes wrong, for example if the roof falls in, they will just send in another robot. Those sorts of things will happen. We have not got to that stage yet, and while we are waiting to get to that stage that is where the battle is. We just have to hang on.

I would like to quote one example of what has happened in Victoria between Western Mining Corporation Ltd and the Victorian Government. The Victorian Government's protection of a colony of extremely rare squirrel gliders and three species of orchids near Stawell has angered the Western Mining Corporation. The managing director of Western Mining, Mr Hugh Morgan, said:
The protection would affect Western Mining's capacity to extend its mining operations into Stawell and the local people would make a judgment on the wisdom of their decision.

The judgment was made on 1 October. Obviously the people of Victoria did not want Western Mining. This epitomises the battle between the environmentalists and the mining industry. Here we have a huge company making large profits and trying once again to exert its control over government and the majority of the people. I guess that Mr Morgan would say, `So what. Why worry about a few squirrel gliders and three species of orchids?' As a government should we say, `Why should we worry about these particular things? Maybe they are found somewhere else'?

We should look carefully at what these large companies are doing. They are exerting continual pressure on government and people. Huge amounts of money are going into expensive advertising campaigns. One has only to look at what some of those people in the forest industries are doing, with the glossy literature that comes across our desks every day and the big ads they put in the news- papers. They are really trying hard to break down what has been built up over many years amongst the large number of people who are concerned for our environment. It is a battle that will rage on but I am quite certain that we environmentalists will win. If Mr Morgan and his company did destroy some endangered animal or rare orchid, maybe we should say to them, `You have killed off that orchid. You will have to produce another one'. Maybe with genetic engineering or some new technology they could do it, but it would cost a lot of money. How much would it cost? I do not know. It may be millions of dollars. That is the sort of proviso we should put on these companies. A lot of them do not care at all for our environment. All they are interested in is a short term gain and how many dollars they can make in a week.

Tourism and conservation go hand in hand. The majority of tourists do not come to Australia to look at buildings, even though we have been told that a lot of Australians come to this building just to have a look at it. The majority of tourists come out to look at our outback and our environment-the Olgas, Ayers Rock, Kakadu, the Great Barrier Reef and South West Tasmania. They are the sorts of things people want to look at and they are the sorts of things we have to look after. Just imagine the situation if we had let the Hugh Morgans of this world loose: none of those areas would be left. What would happen to our tourism industry? People would not come. They do not want to see a Ranger uranium mine and a great hole in the ground. They do not want to see radioactive tailings running into creeks and things like that. They want to see the environment in its natural state.

Australia is a very rich country and it is in a unique position. We can afford to put aside these areas. We do not have to mine and we do not have to cut down trees. We are very lucky. If we can afford to prevent that and prevent it for the next 10 years, I have no doubt that our children, who will be in positions of power then, will not allow it to happen. TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the estimates of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I intend to address the very strange events surrounding the Government's No. 1 policy goal-the establishment of a casino in Canberra prior to Australian Capital Territory self-government. On 8 December 1987 the then Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories-the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown)-announced that Federal Cabinet had agreed in principle to a major development representing an expected $400m investment for section 19 in Civic. However, the former Minister's claim of a $400m investment in the development was ridiculed by an independent feasibility study which valued the development at $129m. To that figure needs to be added the cost of a library and theatre, variously estimated at $40m, giving a final figure of $169m. As can be clearly seen, there is a $231m discrepancy between the Government's figures and those of the independent feasibility study.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I am speaking of the costs involved in the development of Canberra's section 19, I refer the Committee to the Canberra Times of 13 October last. As reported in that newspaper, the release of a report by Sydney theatre consultants Tom Brown and Associates detailing the need for an new arts centre in the ACT was immediately used by this month's Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) in another desperate attempt to force the people of Canberra into accepting a casino. It was the same old threat: no casino, no arts centre. I say to the Minister that the people of Canberra are not so easily intimidated. Their continuing strong stand against Labor's casino is as firm as ever.

A not insignificant sum of taxpayers' money was spent by the Government on establishing an informal social impact study team to obviate the need for a formal environmental impact statement and to fulfil the substance of the law relating to the requirements under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. The study team in its final report, despite the fact that it was a less than confident report, gave the go-ahead to the Government's proposal and, in doing so, exceeded its terms of reference. Despite the go-ahead, paradoxically in its report the team said:

The message the industry conveys is that the comprehensive regulations used in this country have prevented any misconduct or illegal activities in the casinos. However, the team has found that Australia's casinos are not completely trouble free as some reports would suggest. Contrary to much of the rhetoric about the `squeaky clean' nature of Australian casinos, there in fact have been some control problems associated directly or indirectly with Australian casino developments.
The report went on to say:
Laundering as a major problem in casinos, particularly as it is often linked with drug trafficking.
Later the report added:
If a casino is ever built in Canberra, the team would expect the issue of laundering to pose serious problems for Canberra regulators, as it has elsewhere.
The report continued:

The team was shown evidence of an unsuccessful attempt in Australia to `plant' members of a crime `family' in casino operations. Police who have been closely involved with casino investigations and gaming law enforcement presented a view that while the licensing and investigation procedures seem to have been successful in the short term, they were concerned that the problem could escalate in the long term.

The study team did not identify in its report the casino in question. However, I can tell the Committee that it was the Adelaide casino. The expensive taxpayer-funded study raised one example in its report. I wish to add examples of other incidents which have occurred in relation to Australian casinos in the 1980s and late 1970s. An offender charged with fraud offences on a major building society was found to be in the process of organising a worldwide stud poker championship with a casino being the final venue. Evidence is held by police that an amount of $500,000 was to be invested in the venture by the late Carlo Gambino, head of the New York Gambino crime family and boss of bosses of the American Mafia. A former Lieutenant-Governor for the State of Nevada tried to negotiate equity participation in an Australian casino project through a British merchant bank, allegedly involving an amount of $20m. At the time the applicant was the subject of investigations by United States authorities in respect of money paid to organised crime figures, including Jake Lansky, out of the profits of a Nevada casino.

There is the case of a former Australian State police deputy commissioner being involved with a Macao casino group and this group's connection to an Australian company being the parent company of a casino operator. Then there is the case of the American hotel operator being granted a casino licence in Australia, notwithstanding evidence to the effect that a similar licence application by that operator in the United States had been refused because of incidents and associations involving organised crime identities. In addition, there is the matter of a misleading prospectus for one casino project. I could stand here all day quoting further examples; however, I think I have made my point sufficiently on this occasion. Numerous cases similar to these, presented in confidential police material to casino inquiries in New South Wales and Victoria, were key considerations in not allowing casinos in those States. One of the many Trojan horses used by the Government against the people of Canberra has been the much touted tourism bonanza. However, Australian casinos have not been particularly successful as long or short term tourist drawcards. For instance, Cairns, in far north Queensland, has recorded much stronger tourism growth without a casino than Townsville with a casino.

Over recent years the financial press has often reported that many Australian casinos, large and small, have not achieved expected financial results. A contributing factor has been a lower level of tourist patronage than forecast. To illustrate this point, I draw the attention of the Committee to the May 1987 report of the Sydney stockbrokers, James Capel Rivkin, on three Australian casinos. The report corrected the common belief that casinos could be regarded as tourism stocks, as it rightly pointed out that as the novelty factor dissipated in the first six months, residents of the casino city quickly come to constitute the bulk of the patronage. Another of the Trojan horses trotted out by the Government is the assertion that the revenue base of the Australian Capital Territory needs to be expanded and that a casino will, in large part, address this need. The forecast is that $5.4m to $6m will be raised per year from a casino tax. However, the latest available figures show that the amount of tax paid by each of Australia's five small casinos was well under half this amount. Of these, only Wrest Point, Australia's oldest casino, paid more than $2m, less than half of the estimate for Canberra's proposed small casino.

A further shortcoming of the social impact study report is its failure to indicate whether the original revenue predictions for Australia's other casinos were realised, thus allowing a comparison to be made. The James Capel Rivkin report also illustrates the under-performance of Australian casinos. The report begins with the following acid observations:

The three listed casino trusts looked like good investments until they began to operate. The sharemarket's initial enthusiasm turned to disgust as all three failed to reach their prospectus forecasts. Now that all three have substantially under-performed the market it is time to look for opportunities.
In conclusion, a casino in Canberra will expose the national capital to organised crime infiltration for supposed economic and tourism benefits that are very much in doubt.

TALK.START.PARA: —In joining in the committee debate on the appropriations for the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories--

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth recording the importance of the portfolio responsibilities of the Department, which the Federal Government has recognised by increasing the appropriation to $598.7m for 1988-89-a 34 per cent increase over the appropriation for 1987-88. As honourable members will know, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts is conducting an inquiry into land degradation and the commitment of the Federal Government to environment protection bodes well should the Committee seek funding support for its eventual recommendations in relation to the inquiry. I also commend the Government and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) for the increased funding which they have provided in support of protection for our rainforests and for the protection of the Great Barrier Reef. Both conservation areas were subjects of reports made by the former Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation and the recommendations of the Committee have been largely taken up by the Federal Government.

This is a good opportunity to refer to one of them-the protection of the Great Barrier Reef. We recommended in the report which was brought down in November 1985 that the Commonwealth Government continue to provide funds above and beyond other research funding to allow full implementation of a program of research that was recommended by the Crown of Thorns Starfish Advisory Committee. We also recommended that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority give urgent priority to developing a research program to develop more efficient crown of thorns starfish population control techniques. There is no doubt that those recommendations were taken up by the Government, and I certainly commend the Government for that.

The other report to which I want to refer relates to the protection of the Greater Daintree which was brought down in August 1984. In that case we recommended that the Commonwealth Government complete its assessment of World Heritage status as a matter of urgency and, if the assessment concludes that the area is of World Heritage value, that the Commonwealth Government, after consultation with the Queensland Government, proceed with the World Heritage nomination as soon as possible. Of course, as we all know, the Commonwealth Government did attempt to consult with the Queensland Government. But the Queensland Government chose to be intransigent, not to recognise the value of the area and, in fact, even attempted-it is still doing so-to work against the Federal Government's aim to protect probably one of the most unique rainforests in the world.

Another matter I would like to refer to in committee is the problem of feral animals. Whilst the topic will no doubt feature in the land degradation report of the Standing Committee, it is of such outstanding importance that I believe urgent steps must be taken to eradicate feral animals as early as possible. Last weekend the Australian Conservation Foundation held its national conference in Sydney. Dr Mark Stafford Smith of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Division of Wildlife and Rangelands Research presented disturbing information on the increasing destruction that is presently caused by successive invasions of rabbits, cats, dogs, foxes, buffaloes, brumbies, donkeys, camels and pigs in Australia's huge arid zone. Not only are the arid lands becoming degraded, but, worse still, the feral animals are destroying the natural habitat for Australian wildlife. It was perhaps a bit unfortunate that the Deputy Chairman, the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie), was unable to accompany us on that occasion because he had electorate commitments.

Unfortunately, some animal liberationists have been calling for a halt to the killing of donkeys and brumbies. It has to be said that such calls are misplaced because feral animals are directly responsible for the extinction of the western quoll, the greater stick-nest rat, a number of species of wallabies and mice, the bettong, the lesser bilby and the dunnart, all of which are, of course, well known to the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding), who is at the table. Many other species are close to extinction or exist only in small pockets outside the arid zone. In an article in the Australian of 10 October, Dr Smith was quoted as saying:
`Proportionately, the arid lands have suffered worst of all in Australia's generally poor record of native mammal extinctions since European settlement,'. . .
`The extinctions are not just a matter of historical interest and philosophical sorrow; they are continuing. They represent an extraordinary loss of a uniquely Australian heritage.'

I have already made comments abut the severe cuts in funding for the CSIRO. But I cannot help noting that Dr Smith, as a CSIRO scientist, is undertaking research work of enormous importance for the preservation of Australia's heritage at a time when the funding of CSIRO is being cut back.

Perhaps I should warn honourable members that we should not upset CSIRO scientists too much. At present we are all suffering from a plague of bogong moths. I am told that some CSIRO scientists are responsible for this plague and that they actually engineered it! They tell me that if the Government does not restore CSIRO's funding, the next plague will be of European wasps.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will get bigger.
—I think we will have to be rather careful. As the honourable member for Hindmarsh says, they could be far more dangerous than bogong moths.

SPEECH.PARA: I have mentioned how pleased I was at the increased funding for the conservation and protection of the Great Barrier Reef. However, I would again like to point out that these cutbacks in the funding of the science budget must inevitably have adverse effects on the protection of the environment. One cannot view such appropriations in isolation. In this respect I am thinking particularly of the Australia Institute of Marine Science. The Institute is performing excellent research work into the causes of the plague of the crown of thorns starfish for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, yet the Institute has suffered a cut in funds which will result in the loss of one staff member for each of the next three years. Obviously the loss of staff will have some effect on the crown of thorns starfish program. The scientists coordinate their work in allied areas of research. Whilst it is commendable that the Federal Government provides increased funding for essential environmental protection, it is shortsighted in cutting back on funding at the same time in allied areas of scientific research which are associated with environmental protection.

I had the opportunity last week to inspect an exhibition by the CSIRO Division of Forestry and Forest Products, which displayed research work in support of increased production and the improved conservation of our forests. This display was held in one of the committee rooms of Parliament House. It was an excellent display, for which I commend the Division. But I was most concerned to learn that the average age of scientists employed in the Division is increasing, with nobody under 37 years of age. Why are young scientists not coming to work for the CSIRO? Obviously it is because they are worried about its future.

I was glad to see that the Division of Forestry and Forest Products is working on the problem of the greenhouse effect. An understanding of what might happen to the conservation of Australia's coastal zone mangrove swamps, as a result of the rising sea levels due to the warming of the atmosphere resulting from the greenhouse effect, is crucial. Again, such research work is not done in isolation, and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, the Australian Institute of Marine Science, a number of university departments and the CSIRO, all work together in attempting to solve these ecological problems. If the funds of any one or more of these bodies are cut, there will inevitably be a negative effect on the total research effort which is so crucial for protecting the Australian environment. I was pleased to note that the Government has decided that it will assist in research on the greenhouse effect and the problems of a possible rising of the sea-levels and the tides for Pacific Ocean countries in our area. Such rising sea-levels could very seriously affect the economies of those countries, as indeed they will affect those in the coastal zones of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good decision.

—As the honourable member for Hotham said, it is a very good decision. It is one that we on this side of the House all applaud. I hope that the Commonwealth Government will take into account some of the comments I am making. We cannot isolate one area of research from another. If the funds for CSIRO are cut back that unfortunately will have some effect on the commendable research work that is being undertaken in the protection of our environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, in its Budget for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in this year, has acknowledged that Australia has currently within it some 75,000 illegal immigrants. The computer services of the Department have been promised an improvement since the current Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) was the relevant Minister some five years ago. This means that the detection of illegal immigrants has been more difficult. The entry of people into Australian becomes less certain and the capacity to keep information services available to the tourist industry has become restricted.

SPEECH.PARA: There are techniques available to the Department to assure the Australian Government and the Australian people that there is an accurate knowledge of what people are in Australia and why they are here. It is up to date, precise and on line. Of course, this process has raised the prospect of illegal immigrants fighting the Australian Government and the Australian people for their claims of residency through the courts. In fact, half the appeals that are made by illegal immigrants to stay in Australia are supported by legal aid. It seems a crazy idea to me that the Australian people should fund those making a claim to stay in Australia by their own resources, even though those people are illegally here. The cost of this process is not known.

Successive questions to the Attorney-General's Department have failed to indicate or glean any information as to the cost to the Australian people of this process. There are known cases where the extent of legal aid has been high as $1m for one single case in the Australian High Court. That is a tragic way of approaching an important area such as immigration and ethnic affairs. The cost that we do know of to the Australian people of illegal immigrants is at least $130m made up of taxes unpaid and of support to illegal immigrants by way of Medicare and welfare payments. As I said, there have been five Ministers in five years in this Department, and the Government, because of its lack of attention to the important area of immigration and ethnic affairs, has reduced a 1983 program which was substantially a program of skilled, professional and managerial migration to one which is substantially unskilled or semi-skilled. The percentage of skilled migrants has dropped from 50 per cent to a current 17, 18 or 19 per cent as Department's estimates for the current year show. That has brought about pressure and stress within the Australian community and, as Dr Stephen FitzGerald says in his comprehensive report, there is grave danger that the immigration program that Australia needs is being rejected by the Australian people.

There has been a ramshackled approach to the administration of the Department to the extent that despite advice, the Government faced an out-turn, an overrun, for the 1987-88 program which would have meant an annual intake of 190,000 to 200,000 people. That program had to be short-circuited in February this year to prevent that overrun. There was a substantial overrun despite the action taken by the Government. It was basically in the areas of unskilled and semi-skilled migrants. It is not good enough. The Government needs to give attention to these important areas of administration. The Government has not given the Australian people the assurances that they need in regard to the business migration program. It is an important program and essential to Australia's future. The Auditor-General, in his September report, was extremely critical of the processes for examination and verification that should be conducted in the business migration program.

On the other hand, the Opposition parties have released their policies which indicate that there will be care and control taken in the conduct of Australia's immigration program. The program will be carefully controlled and balanced. It will concentrate on those migrants who can supply skill, knowledge, education or investment to Australia. We believe that immigration is important and that it should run at a greater level than it is currently. Immigration should comprise economically independent migrants who are young, educated and employable, who bring and create investment, and who provide a greater capacity for the Australian economy to respond to world pressures. Such an immigration program would allow us to absorb the proportion of the program which is economically dependent, whether it be aged, parents or refugees. It must be balanced in the sense that there should be a capacity to have a migration program which encourages people as they arrive in Australia to be job creators rather than job takers.

The Opposition's program is fair and retains close family reunion as a fundamental part of that balanced program, but it does place emphasis on attracting immigrants with skills, capital and a spirit of enterprise. We are proud, as an Opposition, of our part in accepting refugees from Indo-China and offering a safe haven and security for those families under threat. Currently the Government is reducing that program from Indo-China and seeks to ignore some of the claims that people from the communist bloc countries make for refugee immigration. There has been a switch to those who, under the discretion of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), seek to escape right wing regimes, even though they are not recognised as refugees by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

The selection of migrants under our policy will be without regard to race, religion or country of origin, but the Australian Government must have the right to say who can become a resident of Australia. It is important that the Australian Government is in control of the immigration program. That has not been the case. It is not just the criticisms of the Opposition in this regard. Stephen FitzGerald, in his report, clearly enunciated page after page of criticism on the way in which the Government has conducted its immigration program. Many of those comments by FitzGerald are supported by the Australian people. We believe that there should be greater attention than has been given in the Budget to the recognition of overseas qualifications and professional skills to allow people to upgrade their qualifications and to make a full contribution to Australia.

We will be offering a new priority to English language programs to allow people to feel at home and to be able to earn their living when they arrive. Australian citizenship will regain the proper emphasis and importance under a changed administration in Australia. We will also be increasing the minimum residency from two years to four years. Illegal immigrants will be denied access to welfare and legal aid. They have no claims except under exceptional circumstances and the claims that they make now are extravagant and not warranted. The migration selection procedures will be streamlined under our administration, and people will know whether they can come to Australia, instead of waiting in long queues and perhaps becoming illegal immigrants or queue jumping. In our services to migrant communities, we will be placing emphasis on the needs of aged migrants, women and migrant families in the home, at school and in the workplace.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to target my comments in the area of local government because it has been an issue in recent times that has created some controversy. SPEECH.PARA: Again, the Labor Party established the first ministry for local government. I specifically refer to the Hon. Again, the Labor Party in government instituted the national inquiry into local government finance. Following that inquiry, again this Government introduced the system of untied grants, a new local government financial assistance scheme, a new Act, that gave a new emphasis to the more disadvantaged councils. Regrettably, we found in Queensland that often the money was distributed not on a basis of need or population, but on political ideology. We found regrettably, with Sir Robert Sparkes, that a council that he had a link with always seemed to get more than it deserved in comparison with the more needy authorities.

We introduced the concept of requiring local government to be consulted in determining the principles governing the distribution of funds. It had not happened before. TALK.START.PARA: —I was relating to the Committee some of the figures I have gleaned from a study of the shires in my own State of Queensland with the intention of pointing out how difficult it must be for those shires, with limited numbers of people and therefore a very limited rate base, to carry out the functions that we expect of them. INTERJECT.PARA: Surely there is a need to start rethinking the boundaries of our local authorities. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 and the estimates for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I have had the opportunity both privately and publicly to speak at length on this subject. I preface my speech around the one Australia policy in the context of the immigration debate. I was involved with an Australian Broadcasting Corporation Four Corners program. The honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) may laugh. One facet of my involvement was the role I played for the Japanese NHK TV production Under the Shade of a Coolabah Tree. I was derided by some middle class Australians who thought that that portrayal was beneath the dignity of Australians. The Four Corners crew travelled around a marginal seat in Adelaide trying to get an assessment of the views shared by people following the immigration debate that was raging in Australia several months ago. I am very comfortable with the one Australia policy. In the few minutes I have in which to speak I hope to be able to elaborate more on that. What disappoints me is the interpretation of the immigration policy by sections of the media-an interpretation fuelled by the Australian Labor Party and the Hawke Government.
—Do you mean that they tell the truth?

—The honourable member will have the opportunity to understand that it was his Leader and Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who said that he wished to send Indo-Chinese refugees back to where they came from. By the admission of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, as referred to earlier by the shadow Minister for immigration, local government and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), under this Government five Ministers have attempted to service the immigration portfolio. I honestly believe that immigration is still vital for Australia's future. The statement `populate or perish' is still very true and evident. I stand by my public statement that race should not play any part in our migration selection process. It is a cornerstone of the Opposition policy and is stated in our policy document.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me dwell on social cohesion. I am reminded of an article written by the late and great Professor Julius Sumner Miller. He was asked: `Do you think the world will find peace? Will countries and nationalities find peace with each other?'. He may even have prefaced his answer with, `Why is it so?'. He said: `Families, brothers and sisters have irreconcilable disputes and feuds, yet we are asking and expecting the world to be at peace'. Australia is a very tolerant country. Our social cohesion is not under threat but is perhaps under pressure. Australia is a country only 200 years old in terms of new settlement, yet in the last 40 years we have, as I said, recognised the need to populate or perish. As an emerging country, a fantastic country with a free spirit, we have inherited 150 new and different nationalities, religions and cultures. Of course we are going to be under some sort of pressure, but it is a pressure we can live with and overcome. Certainly, we are not threatened. We have the pseudo allegations that our Asian-Pacific rim trade is in jeopardy. However, Asian traders for centuries have been free traders. They go where the price is right, including coming to this country and paying for education.

What about one Australia and multiculturalism? Multiculturalism has not failed Australia or we it, yet the word `multiculturalism' seems to be at the heart of the debate. We have horticulture, agriculture and now multiculture. We love hijacking words and categorising people into areas. We had emigrants, then they became new Australians. They were then known as ethnics. Now we have to know them as multicultures-some new pathologists' yoghurt. My life, my family and my country have been enriched and embellished by the impact of migrants who have come to Australia. I am certainly grateful for and proud of the contribution to our arts, theatre, cuisine, fashion, culture, language and lifestyle. As I said before, Australia has gone from a country, probably 40 years ago, of braces worn outside shirts, felt hats and sauce on our steak to the lifestyle we have today as a result of the impact of migrants.

TALK.START.PARA: —I still put sauce on my steak.

—We do, but it is a different sort of sauce. Certainly, in Adelaide, my home city, the migrant community has made a considerable impact. I respect those migrants as people who have contributed to the welfare of Australia-as Australians. Certainly, they do not have Anglo-Saxon sounding names. There is Lord Mayor Steve Condors; the builders, the Koiredis Brothers; Michael Angelakis; Caj Amadio; Prino Caeon; Walter Ling-one of the best restaurateurs in Adelaide; Nerio Ferraro, President of the Norwood Football Club, one of the greatest Australian Rules football clubs in South Australia; Wolff Blass; and Max Schubert. They are not Anglo-Saxon sounding names. However, they are the names of people who have come to Australia and made a big impact on our lives, our culture and our future. If we were fair dinkum and analysed the word `multiculturalism' we would have to be honest and say it envelops the ethnic community. It is a name that has been given to the ethnic community. What about middle ground Australia? What title does it afford us? Why do we need a title? None of us needs a title because we have one Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Do not let anyone forget that less than 50 years ago tens of thousands of Australian men and women offered their lives in the defence of this country and went abroad to do it. They went to Korea, Vietnam, New Guinea and Hong Kong. Why? To give Australia and Australians a free and democratic country to live in. There is no greater sacrifice than to offer one's life for one's fellow man and country. Yet when we dare to talk about social cohesion, multiculturalism, immigration or of 150 different races, colours, creeds and religion we are branded as racial bigots.

I recently attended several Vietnamese functions, including the Children's New Moon Festival at St Clair youth centre. The Catholic church service was ministered by Father Augusta. The music was supplied by a teenage Vietnamese orchestra. I am sure the children would have liked to turn up the amplifiers and get into a bit of heavy metal but the discipline and music supplied cut through any language barrier. Whether you sing Amazing Grace in Vietnamese or English the three-part harmony still has the same meaning.

One of my greatest pleasures was to join a group of Vietnamese men and women at Athol Park in Adelaide. These men had served in the South Vietnamese army and had escaped or migrated to Australia even though Bob Hawke said he did not want them. This fundraising barbecue was devised so these dedicated men could raise funds to travel to Melbourne last weekend and march arm in arm with the Vietnam veterans from Australia and around the world. It could have been an Aussie barbecue except that the names were different-Mr Quang, Mr Tran and Mr Ho-but the motives certainly were not. The Prime Minister is always one to try to score a political point, even at the expense of the Melbourne Age today, but he missed out when the Italian President, Mr Cossiga, was here in Canberra. He did not even have the common courtesy to refer to a Labor Party colleague, Mr Con Sciacca, an Italian-born member of parliament. Certainly, Senator Panizza was warmly welcomed by Mr John Howard.

What of the one Australia policy? At the Seoul Olympics the soccer team was coached by Frank Arok and skippered by Charlie Yankos and Frank Farina. When it scored the winning goal against the Germans, did we stand as one and barrack for multiculture? We did not because we were respecting Australia, as we did when Duncan Armstrong, Debbie Flintoff-King and the women's hockey team brought home gold medals for Australia. Song of Australia was what we were supporting and I believe in the one Australia policy. Whatever our origin, our background or our birthplace, once we are established here Australia is the country we want to support. The top rating Comedy Company enables us to laugh at ourselves. Con, the Greek fruiterer, I am sure would be a great follower of Dr Theophanous. We can sit back and laugh at our humour. We can laugh at Vince Sorrenti. That is what part of our culture is about.

My daughter attends a college in Adelaide. It is not full of Anglo-Saxon sounding names but it is not a multicultural school. It is a school in Australia for Australian students. I support our attitude to migration. Certainly it is not racist and I would not be led down that path. I commend our immigration policy.
