TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 September last, the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) moved a motion relating to the League of Rights. This was seconded by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). I do not want to take issue with the terms of that motion but something was said within the speech of the honourable member for Capricornia which has been drawn to my attention as being incorrect. In attacking the League of Rights, the honourable member quite correctly referred to human rights, individual liberties and so on, which should be included in any discussion of the League of Rights. But it is important that the rights of those who were mentioned be safeguarded.

SPEECH.PARA: The person who has approached me as having been misquoted and, he believes, dealt with in an unsatisfactory way by the honourable member for Capricornia, is Mr Michael Darby. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would understand that Mr Michael Darby, one who in Oxley gave his preferences to the Labor Party ahead of the Liberal Party, is not one who would normally be approved of by the Liberal Party. But I have a concern about the accuracy of reports about people. I believe Mr Darby's rights have to be respected as much as anybody else's in this community. I have received a statement from Mr Darby in reply to the suggestion that he is a leading member of the League of Rights and one of its main apologists which is something put forward by the honourable member for Capricornia. Mr Darby, in a note to me has said:
I have never been a supporter, nor a member, nor a leader of the League of Rights, nor have I ever met its director.
That is, Mr Eric Butler. He continued:

Since around 1959 I have been an opponent of Douglas Credit, central to the League's economic policies, and I have often warned that the League of Rights will jump on any available political bandwagon for the sake of self-promotion.

I say this in order to correct the record. I have no reason to believe that Mr Darby is telling me anything other than the truth. I do not wish to detract from the general argument put forward by the honourable member for Capricornia, or the honourable member for Gwydir, but it is quite important that, in raising issues of the kind they did, the individual rights, liberties and prerogatives of the citizens of Australia be respected. I think, therefore, Mr Darby, who does not have the opportunity to reply to these things in this House, should have the record corrected on his behalf.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, Lucindale is one of the more fertile areas of Australia. It is a green and pleasant land down there. Several years ago there was a farmer down in that area, a Mr Lance Hurst. Mr Hurst was a very successful farmer in the area but I think he felt he developed his farm as far as it could go and in middle age he decided he would seek a new venture. He went to Western Australia and bought the Sturt Meadows Station, one million acres in the Leonora Shire. When Mr Hurst bought the station it was very badly run down. It had been badly managed for some time and overstocked in some areas. Fences were in a very dilapidated state. It was a very courageous move and I think he paid more for it than he intended. He and his children and his wife moved in and they have done a very commendable job in returning that station to being a highly productive unit. I was there recently on an Agriculture Department trip, a field day, looking at the soil and pasture regeneration. This field day was actually sponsored by Elder Smith Ltd. One could not help but be impressed by the work that has been done there and it is a great tribute to Mr Hurst and his family. They have spent so much effort, so much money and time in actively regenerating that country. They have had many failures. They have tried many species of plants and they have had some considerable success. One can see with one's own eyes the great benefit they have bestowed on that country.

SPEECH.PARA: Soil degradation and salinity are the biggest environmental problems facing Australia today. These are problems that face every person in Australia. Everyone, even in the most urban areas, in the capital cities, is affected by these twin evils of soil degradation and salinity. It is to the credit of this Government that we have started to recognise the problem and, for the first time, are funding work in this area. I believe the funding is nothing like significant enough, and over time I expect to see big increases. It saddens me that the various conservation groups, the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Wilderness Society and others, have never really recognised this problem, and I think the reason is that one cannot really pack up the old four-wheel drive and go and look at salinity; soil degradation creeps up on one. Often one can look at country that has a lot of growth and the casual observer would not realise that all the perennial species have gone and that colonising plants have taken over, which have no economic value. They crowd out areas and make it difficult for anything else to regenerate.

The Conservation Foundation and the Wilderness Society have never really had an interest in this area, although they have recently started to claim an interest. The Government must grab hold of this agenda as the most important aspect of the environment for Australia and must show leadership and be out there in the forefront, or else this too will be taken over by the these often ill-informed urban-based bodies.

To my view, they can have no credibility while they oppose the kangaroo cull. It is absolute nonsense to say to a pastoralist that his cooperation is required and he should reduce his stocking levels and remove stock from an area, and then have that area inundated with kangaroos. One can see in several defence line experiments on Sturt Meadows, where there were absolutely no sheep at all, the amount of damage done by excessive kangaroo numbers. The fact that the Conservation Council and the Wilderness Society will not, despite the overwhelming evidence, support the kangaroo cull totally destroys their credibility in respect to soil regeneration.

The irony is that if they are successful and the kangaroo cull is abandoned, pastoralists will be forced to poison kangaroos. Poisoning is far more effective than culling. It will kill all of the kangaroos regardless of age or sex. It will be legal and nothing will be able to be done about it. I do not believe this is what the conservationists or most of the people who support them want, but it will be the consequence of their actions. Their irresponsibility must be recognised and they must come to terms with the reality of the situation and support the good work done by the various departments of agriculture and the pastoralists. In conclusion, I would just like to pay a tribute to Mr Don Burnside, the officer in charge of the agriculture department in Kalgoorlie--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a subject concerning the lives of young Australians and the future of our nation. The profile is not one of fame and acclaim, usually offered to our sports men and women. I wish to offer my warm congratulations to the Australian Jaycees and their Outstanding Young Australian Awards for 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: As you will be aware, Mr Acting Speaker, the Jaycees are not a religious group, bearing the initials of our Saviour. The Jaycees have been in Australia as a recognised community body for 55 years, arising out of the Chamber of Commerce junior groups, or junior chamber, hence Jaycees.

I wish to pay tribute to the South Australian chapter and its eleventh Anniversary Luncheon held yesterday at Adelaide's Strathmore Hotel, in my electorate. The judging panel-consisting of the Hon. Diana Laidlaw, MLC, Mr Kevin Duggan, QC, Mr Michael Shanahan, Deputy Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board, and Mr Richard Maloney, Chairman and Coordinator-considered seven outstanding candidates, selecting five to go on to the national awards in November. Certificates were awarded to Michael McIntyre, nominated by the Wheelchair Sports Association of South Australia. Michael is truly an outstanding young Australian. He is employed as the activity supervisor at the Hillcrest Hospital and is currently in Seoul competing in the disabled olympics.

Joanne Baird was nominated by the District Council of Millicent. Her academic skills in science, chemistry and mathematics are duplicated in music and the arts. Joanne is currently studying at the College of Advanced Education and is a member of the Flinders Street School of Music.

Winton Ankor, nominated by the Adelaide Central Mission, shares an interest very dear to me, the learning for life drug education program. Both Winton and I are well aware that drugs are a very real hazard to the school girls and boys of Australia. The learning for life program is a constructive attack on the evils of the drug industry and, as instanced by the drug forum I convened in Adelaide recently, I am totally committed to it.

Bruce Macky was nominated by the State Bank of South Australia, a fitting backer for a capable nominee. Bruce has a degree in commerce and administration, with an economics major. Bruce's track record covers a broad spectrum from Harvard University through to scouting.

Elizabeth Newman represents the essence of Australian initiative and ingenuity. A self-employed designer, manufacturer and distributor of hand-knitted designer label sweaters, Elizabeth has markets for her Aussie goods in Asia, Japan, the United States and Canada. Testimony to the quality of Liz's endeavour is the Walt Disney corporation giving her the rights to produce garments featuring Disney characters.

Gunter Scheide was nominated by the Whyalla Jaycees, where he has administered the finances of the Corporation of the City of Whyalla for more than 10 years. Gunter has displayed an outstanding community spirit, being instrumental in helping to obtain grants for the building of a senior citizens hostel and the upgrading of a basketball stadium.

Finally, but by no means least, Peter Schiller was nominated by the Paraplegic and Quadriplegic Association of South Australia. Peter has spent much of his time fighting the ignorance in the community regarding the disabled. With a group of friends, this remarkable young Australian founded and incorporated Alternative Lifestyles for the Disabled. After moving into private accommodation, he set about establishing the First Regency Park Scout Troop.

This is the exceptional calibre of the nominees for the Australian Jaycees Outstanding Young Australian Awards. So as the member for Adelaide, it was indeed an honour to be in the company of seven great Australians. Politics, multiculturalism, Jobsearch and the jobs, employment and training scheme were not mentioned once. Another credit was for the president elect for 1988-89, Ms Mary Adams, formerly of Brinkworth, who in the Jaycees fiftieth year is the first woman to hold this position. My congratulations are extended to her and her committee.
In conclusion, I think it is pertinent to repeat the Jaycees' creed:

We believe: That faith in God gives meaning and purpose to human life, that the Brotherhood of Man transcends the sovereignty of nation, that economic justice can best be won by free men through free enterprise. That Governments should be of laws rather than of men. That earth's great treasure lies in human personality. And that service to humanity is the best work of life.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Telecommunications Commission, or Telecom as we know it only too well, demonstrated amazingly poor timing with the release of its annual report last week. As the report was being tabled in the House by the Government, boldly showing a profit in 1987-88 of $777m, a senior executive was announcing to the media that the use of a basic telephone service would cost more after 1 November. Here was a perfect example of Telecom putting its foot in it-a public-owned monopoly with a profit figure for last year almost as much as the Government collected overall in fringe benefits tax, telling Australia, `But that's not enough, we want more and more and you are going to pay for it'.

SPEECH.PARA: Regrettably, Telecom's revenue-raising activities are a reflection of the Government's mismanagement of the economy. Concern for the plight of ordinary Australians has taken second place in this Government's scheme of things. We have recently seen the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the man who would be Prime Minister, living it up around the world, telling other countries how great he is. Meanwhile, back home families are preparing themselves for the impact of another round of interest rate increases and a lower standard of living.

We need look no further than this Government to find the trigger for the latest rise in the cost of local calls. The Government announced at this year's Premiers Conference that Telecom would have to pay payroll tax to the States from July, at a cost of $140m to Telecom. Of course, we all know that in the same breath the Government took away funding to the States of $126m as a result. We now know Telecom's response to the Government's decision. First, phone rentals went up by 7 per cent for businesses and 3 per cent for domestic users, and local calls will cost 21c from next month.

An interesting fact is that Telecom will recoup only $108m of the $140m. Clearly, without the payroll tax imposition Telecom could have been in a position to actually reduce the cost of local calls. In reality though Telecom is not in the business of making life easier for ordinary Australians. Since January 1983, the cost of local calls has risen by a massive 62 per cent. In Western Australia Telecom has introduced a way of making money by making others pay for its capital works responsibilities. I refer specifically to Western Australia because I am advised that Telecom's so-called `enterprise projects policy' is being pursued most zealously in that State. Since 1986 Telecom has required developers of semi-rural residential subdivisions to pay for cabling of the subdivisions.

I do not plan to debate the merits of the policy at this time, but in a particular case in my own electorate, Telecom's inflexibility and obsession with profit has caused it to override yet again its social responsibilities. Mr Arthur Green began developing a semi-rural subdivision called Roseclif Park Estate in 1982. When blocks went on the market in 1985 Telecom had neither introduced its enterprise projects policy nor advised Mr Green that he would be required to contribute under such a policy when it was introduced. So far as Mr Green was aware, telephone services would be made available upon request, in accordance with previous experience. In fact, Telecom first requested a contribution from the developer six days after the first application was made for a phone connection in February 1986.
